If there's one thing the winter season will be remembered fondly for, it'll be the solid moe slice of life anime that came out during that time. For people like me, who enjoy shows like that a lot, it was a rather fun couple of months. Wide variety of SOL proved to be very accessible even to the people who aren't particularly into anime like that. But even before the season, there was one specific show that thousands of fans were really excited about: the new project by Kyoto Animation - Kobayashi-san's Dragon Maid. With some solid, well established name behind the project and aweird name, it's definitely a show that could capture your eye while browsing through the list of winter shows. How was it then? Well, let's start from the beginning. 


*Spoilers included*


Kobayashi wakes up hungover, takes her stomach medicine and gets ready for work. She's just a normal person in a boring world. However, the moment she opens her doors, a giant, green scaled beast pops in front of her face and lets out an almighty roar. The terrified Kobayashi stays in place as some kind of an incantation circle appears before her eyes, and as the bright light blinds her, she looks into it. What comes out.... 

Wait, is that... 

Is that a maid? WITH A DRAGON TAIL AND HORNS? 

That's right ladies and gentlemen, Tohru is a dragon, who escaped her fantasy world after a battle, and after meeting Kobayashi, who offered her to stay at her place in her drunken rant, decided to live alongside humanity. Why? Because she fell in love with that crazy drunk. And so begins the tale of understanding different cultures, love, fun, and an entirely new anime loli dragon fetish. Actually, forget the last one. 


The story starts off rather innocently and weirdly uneventful for something sounding so crazy. I saw very little promising features in it. There were fanservice moments, rather pushy humor and the characters felt off-putting, especially Kobayashi's wild, drunken behavior as she stripped Tohru down. Thankfully, that quickly changes with the introduction of additional characters, the first one being Kanna, a little kid that wandered into the human world in search of Tohru. After that, more and more people decide to hop onto this new "go into the human world" train and soon we got ourselves quite a bunch of misfits that absolutely doesn't fit the world of a simple worker that Kobayashi is. 


Actually, this is one of the most interesting themes of winter - the dragons getting used to living by a completely new set of rules. It isn't handled as if they were completely unknowledgeable about humans, they had those in their world too. They were the equivalent of our fantasy knights, but still. Dragons have a somewhat coherent image of what a human is to them, but it's actually different than ours. Both Tohru and Kanna see them as enemies, a brutal bunch that, as inferior as they are, put up an unnecessary fight and threaten their existence. The development from this point of view goes a long way. All of them, from the ones with an aggressive stance to the ones that simply don't care, start to understand and respect humanity for what it is. They start to see it as a big, coherent, happy family, something that they could never really find in their world. Same goes for the humans. All the people that the dragons get close to start off being fascinated by them, but by the end they befriend those that they considered to be almighty monsters at first.

But, despite trying, those two worlds can't understand each other completely. That's not a bad thing though. They accept each other and find happiness in those differences, Kobayashi has much more fun than she ever had, Tohru can spend time with someone she loves, Kanna can learn and grow alongside those who are more experienced, both in human and dragon things. This peaceful correlation, tranquility amongst the craziness of completely new elements being added to one's viewpoint on the world are especially heartwarming. On top of that it sets up a great foundation for the individual character development that this show visibly aimed for from the very beginning, especially when it comes to the main duo.


Tohru and Kobayashi live in a rather peculiar relationship. One's clearly in love with the other, but she finds it hard to really get into a serious relationship. Tohru acts a bit too immaturely by our standards, it's difficult for Kobayashi to take her words for granted, but the more time they spend together, the more they can really understand what this way of life they're set on means and what could it bring. Problems arise often. Tohru tends to get jealous, not understanding the meaning of pure friendship, acts irrationally and impulsively. All she wants is attention. She wants to feel the love she felt while meeting her and being invited to live with Kobayashi. On the other hand, she also fails to understand that her love interest is just as much in the dark as she is. Kobayashi lived alone for a longer while now, she never got into a relationship like that before. she can see how hard Tohru is trying, but it's hard for her to change her approach on a whim like that, especially with her heavy work schedule and the sudden appearance of this new challenge. Their relationship is the core of the show, something that seamlessly changes on the inside, for example, with the way both of them approach their daily activities in new ways, such as Tohru's responsibilities becoming more diverse, indicating the increasing reliance Kobayashi places on her. On the outside though, this isn't such a common occurrence. There's very few serious dialogues between them, but when they occur, they move their view of one another heavily, like when Kobayashi uncovered her social troubles to Tohru, she accepted them and stopped becoming as pushy with her attempts to get as close as possible in as little amount of time as possible. Things progressed naturally from there on out, they even started to cuddle when sitting at a kotatsu, their dialogues started being even more casual, so they actually started to feel like a couple in a way. It's barely noticeable because of how charismatic and loud this show is at all times, but it's a very important part of this show's writing, and it really says a lot about its masterful scripting.

So as they start to joke around more and more, Kobayashi slowly warms up and changes her attitude, Tohru becomes more reliable and accustomed to the human world and their ethics, we can truly see how important their relationship really is to both of them. Kobayashi can finally find comfort with the place she's at in life, she can rest and have fun by simply being at home, which she talks about numerous times with appreciation, and same goes for Tohru, who, while living in her own world, had to constantly escape from dangers and had her fate decided by her father, or properly enjoy the time she has in between getting thrown around by fate and other people. While both still can't accept each other fully, Kobayashi and Tohru can live together and have a blast while doing so. This way both of them can decide on who they are to themselves and to each other. You simply can't take something like this for granted, not a lot of shows can create such an intricate relationship between the two characters that get so much screen time. But Tohru isn't the only one that changes people's lives. Let's move on to the rest of the dragons.


Kanna also becomes a huge influence on Kobayashi. To me she feels like an adopted child. The way she has to get accustomed to talk with another kids, starts going to school and deal with everyday activities accompanying it (dealing with bullies, sport festival and making friends), how she shines so brightly when she receives the tiniest bit of confirmation of love from Kobayashi, who is her guardian. Once again, it feels like she didn't get those type of things in the other world, just like an adopted child wouldn't get in an orphanage.

As such, she becomes a serious responsibility for Kobayashi, unlike Tohru, who would mostly end up being someone helpful by cleaning and doing fun things. Kanna needs more attention, she needs to grow, find interests, feel the love from her parent, be fed properly, discover new things, just like every child does. This is especially visible in the sports festival episode, where Kobayashi has to work overtime to be able to attend something important to Kanna. It's pretty much a symbol of her leaving her past life behind, but it resonates so strongly because she does it for another person, she dedicates herself to someone else which was unheard of when she lived by herself. Small steps, sure, but this paves the way for her to accept Tohru later on and become a reliable person, so as you can see, no interaction is unimportant here. Not only that, but because Kanna, Kobayashi and Tohru live in such a close relationship, they influence one another through chain reactions. This on the other hand can be noticed in the last episode, when Tohru disappears. Kobayashi and Kanna pretty much stop in their tracks and even start regressing, as more responsibilities fall on her, we realize that despite her growing ability to take on responsibilities, she isn't fully ready to do continue her new way of life by herself, and as such, Kanna also becomes less active and more silent, regressing as well.

Others begin to rely on humans as well, more so than they could probably imagine. Even a dragon like Fafnir, who resented humanity above all else and considers them inferior, has to eventually acknowledge the fact that amongst them there are those who he could consider "hits", even if most of them are "misses". But it's not like the humans don't see anything that's going on. Takiya hangs out with Fafnir and plays games with him (some include Dark Souls, Mario Kart, and anime MMOs. They don't name them, but there is an entire Dark Souls sequence in one episode. This show is great at including references). By allowing Fafnir to live with him, treating him as if he would treat any other human and being open to creating a bond, you can come to a conclusion that he wants to help the dragons as well, just like Kobayashi did. Also, Shouta comes to the point where he feels lost and sad when Lucoa isn't with him. Their relationship is much less important in the long run, but this is an example of a certain change. The two worlds, the human one and the dragon one, are like  two  layers, but instead of one overtaking the other, they end up mixing and continuing to grow. They live in a symbiotic relationship, they can improve one another by simply coexisting, and it's as wonderful as the examples of such relationships that you can see in nature. An improbable encounters between species that don't need each other, but can willingly work together to take some responsibilities off of each other if given a chance (of course only considering the mutualistic ones). It's easily one the most heartwarming natural occurrences, and it's just as adorable in this show, if not more with the added musical and visual side.


From the audiovisual side, Kobayashi is definitely a stand out. It has a rather unique style of being an actual "moeblob" in terms of character design, with a lot of round faces and lack of mouths at specific shots, but that simply adds to the charm. It uses a wide color pallet, the backgrounds look like paintings and the animation is great. KyoAni quality right here. The sound ranges from happy, cheerful and exciting to deep and thoughtful, complementing the switches in tone. It really helps getting in the mood, so the transitioning won't feel sudden. 


I also really want to address the issue that some in the community expressed, that being the accusation of pedophilic intent of some of the scenes where Lucoa pushed Shouta to touching or seeing her breasts, or Kanna (who is actually thousands years old) jumps on top of her friend saying that she wants to get to know her. I thought about it a lot, trust me I did, and I came to a conclusion that while I can't exactly retort those claims, I want people to look at it from a different angle. I absolutely reject the thought that a show that showed me such a beautiful homosexual relationship, a very subtle look at parenting from many different angles and an in-depth look at the understanding and living alongside different types of cultures would just simply show pedophilic content with any sort of evil intent. I know that it's sort of there, and that someone may take it as such, but if you look at how many great lessons and wonderful messages this show sends, I see no reason for it to be considered evil. KyoAni still has a lot to learn in terms of fanservice, which they showed both in Phantom World and Dragon Maid, I'm willing to give them a chance to grow. This show is all about connection, I don't want it to split people because of a couple of scenes. 


All in all, I'm very glad that I gave this show a chance. As should you. This show is a great, fun ride that anyone can enjoy if they are willing to do so. It's heartwarming, pretty, deep, thoughtful, happy or exciting when it needs to. It truly owned the subtlety that it needed, so it could be such a memorable experience. Deep down inside, I know this show will remain in my mind for a long time. It helped me to develop my own views on topics that I haven't thought about before by showcasing different sides of one problem. Do yourself a favor, and try watching Kobayashi-san Chi no Maid Dragon if you feel like watching a solid slice of life. Maybe you'll see even more than I did. 


As always, this is purely my opinion. I highly recommend you to develop you own.

My first instinct was to call Maidragon "offensively bad", but it's much more of a "mindnumbingly bad"-type of anime. There's nothing there. Watching it is no different than staring at a blank screen for twenty minutes; you get the same boring effect and feeling that you've wasted some, if not all, of your time. 
Let me set aside all of my moral issues with the show, because if they haven't bugged you already, you likely don't care. I also don't wish to offend fans of the show when I say that I simply don't get it. Even after giving it a shot, I have noclue why this anime is so popular in both the West and Japan (though Kemono Friends beats it out in the latter area). Anyway, let's move on. 


Maidragon focuses on the comedic mishaps of a group of dragon girls when they find their way to an ordinary woman's apartment. It's presented in a series of sketches which all rely on the viewer to elicit at least one of two reactions: 'this is funny' or 'this is cute'. If you find yourself in the unfortunate situation of not experiencing them, everything falls apart pretty quickly. You start finding plotholes that haven't been addressed and likely never will be: Why would an adult woman let all of these people into her house, especially so quickly, and then get a new apartment just for them? Why isn't anyone suspicious of the numerous people, some of them children, that suddenly appeared in her home? Why are the dragons magical? There's no interest in answering such questions, only finding ways to brush them off with a one-liner or some other sort of joke. Sure, you aren't supposed to pay that much attention to the details, but where is the base of the material? Why should you care, other than through two of the most basic methods of emotional manipulation? You shouldn't. It needs you to be non-inquisitive and readily consumerist to enjoy what little is laid out. It's OK if that much works for you, but it's not quite enough to satisfy me.


Another thing that's likely worth noting is the relentless amount of Shoujo-Ai in the series. There is some vaguely sexual thing between women that happens or is hinted towards at least once every five minutes. As a lesbian myself, I normally wouldn't mind, but this element feels awfully shoehorned in and designed to pander to the (predominately male) otaku audience of the show—like mass-produced lesbian pornography, its existence doesn't do much other than serving an extremely basic 'girls are hot' point of view. If I were still 12, maybe it would seem more realistic or more compatible with my point of view. To pretend that it's some sort of feminist, pro-LGBTQ statement is to ignore literally every other theme within the show itself to reinforce your own beliefs. And that's a story for another post.


That's basically the entire show. I don't think its art or music are worth mentioning (depressingly unusual for a KyoAni show), so there's no point in devoting paragraphs to what I can say nothing about. Regardless, if you're looking for something basic and cute and are less picky about what you watch, it might be for you. Want a bit more to think about or care too much about slice of life shows? Here may not be the best place to start.

Watching this show is like sleeping in a box filled kittens, puppies and magical hugs. It's a fanastic comfort show that makes you laugh and warms your heart with it's likebale characters, wholesome relationships and optimistic world view. It's endearing and enjoyable to watch Tohru adapt to living on earth. The show can be also be suprisingly poignant especially when Tohru has to deal with the possibility of out living Kobayashi. The dragons' back stories are fascinating and I wish I could get more world building. The dragon characters are so damn likeable that I want to know more about their long and complex histories.All in all the show is a great slice of life story with a lot of warmth and heart.

Hmm, the mundane side of things in life. Do they really contain more than just activities described as being unexciting? Well, how about we take that exact question and spice it up with a bit of fantasy and imaginative writing? The result? Say hello to the wonderful slice-of-life anime titled Maid Dragon!
Dragons in a human world. They're powerful, quirky, quite bouncy indeed, and one apparently wears a maid outfit. In the eyes of programmer Kobayashi and ours as well, you can say the ordinary is becoming rather extraordinary... and quickly too! Now, a combination ofoddness and conventionality might be a bizarre thing. But here's where I tell you how this show has succeeded in putting a refreshing twist to the slice-of-life genre. At first glance, it's only a fuzzy and cute display. True, however, there's more to this than just heart-tugging sweetness. These dragons, who have little knowledge about humans, are given the chance to experience the goodness of human nature by meshing with the world of people. Pretty much everything in an everyday life. From what we do, how we communicate, what we enjoy, and how we bond. In their eyes, they are shown all these ordinary circumstances that we find as mundane and repetitive, but to them, they feel a different kind of specialness and become appreciate of it. They've grown attached to it. Like a reflection reminding us that we too can be grateful with an ordinary lifestyle. This, together with Kobayashi who now has her life livened up by eccentricities, speaks for a fun filled with many heartwarmers. And you know what? A fantasy day-to-day full of dragons, I can definitely appreciate such a quirky family.\n\n
Yep. Life is such dullness? Such monotone? Let's erase all that! Because the human world where this family resides in is a world brightened up by the colors of innocence and cartoony toons. Glee replaces humdrums and peculiarity replaces the usual. Every nooks and crannies envisioned from a combination of fantasy and slice-of-life, drizzled with some comedy, are animated with a lot of activity. Hey, even the fan service got that treatment as well, overemphasized or not. There's the blobby highlights nailing down the child-like look while detailed eyes refresh them as the fire-breathing beasts they rightfully are. And to soften everything up, the pastel-styled backgrounds subdue these characters against an ordinary world. As their attachment to the world grows, their expressions show both blissful and heart-warming growths. Which is something wonderful to see. It's even more precious in how there's so many emotions pronounced through the voice acting. Lively, adorable, loving. Each of this brings out Kobayashi's and the dragons' whole personality out to form them as a family. And finishing things off, the soundtracks serve as an addition that harmonize the odd and normal together. While mostly bustling with lightheartedness, the tempo can slow down into a gentle and mellow maturity, paving way to a sincerity this show has its roots in. Oh, plus the catchy opening too. Chu chu yeah!\n\n
So there you have it. Maid Dragon is a slice-of-life show that really knows how to unpack what its genre is all about. It reminds us about the positivity contained within the everyday setting that we live in. The mundane? Not anymore with these dragons. A life of no excitement has now transformed into something truly hearty, and that is certainly a wonderful thing.

Spoilers ahead (after the first paragraph) because I don't know if I can explain some things without saying what they are.
Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid starts off as a cute and funny series, with situations dealing about living at home, having neighbors, moving out, etc. It also points out some anime themes that are dumb or unrealistic such as "anime maids are just cute and nothing else and tarnish the reputation of real maids who actually work really hard", like the author knows and don't want to be yet another generic anime, but at the same time really likes the idea of a dragon maid, orat least that's my interpretation. That is good, you do what you wanna do and try your best, while being generic is bad.


The problem starts about... episode 7 or so. It gets appalling and lacking? There's no interesting living at home/daily life stuff to deal with and the cliché slice of life episodes starts gushing out without any of the show's initial appeal. Kobayashi's Maid Dragon holds a special place in my heart and not just because it is a really damn good show. Let's go back to four months ago. I was bored and didn't know what I wanted to do, so I decided to get into anime. Yeah, it wasn't something like pokemon or attack on titan that got me into anime, I just decided on my own. So I did some research for gateway anime I should watch, which nothing came out of, so I decided to choose a random anime. Yeah that's right, I chose Food Wars, which was a terrible decisions because Ibecame bored after the first episode, so I immediately quit.So I tried to search up some anime memes on youtube, which lead me to anime compilations like ''Aqua being Aqua'' and ''Megumin being Megumin''. This resulted in me watching a compilation about this little girl with a big forehead getting aroused every time this other weird little girl did anything. I thought both looked cute, so I wanted to know which anime they came from. So yes, Kobayashi's Maid Dragon is my first proper anime that I fully watched, but I still want to judge it without my… nostalgia (I guess?) in the way. Get ready for lots of lesbians and don't lewd the dragon loli, this is my review of Kobayashi's Maid Dragon. 


Story: 7/10 {Spoilers!}

Kobayashi gets drunk one day after a long day of work and comes across a dying dragon. She drunkenly helps the dragon and the dragon is saved. Kobayashi somehow manages to get that dragon (who is now in a human form) and even convinces her to be Kobayashi’s Maid. The dragon (named Tohru) accepts it. The nexts day Kobayashi (who has forgot everything that happened the day before) finds Tohru at the door. When Tohru explains everything that happened the day before, Kobayashi first doesn’t want Tohru to be her maid, but later she accepts it. So from here the story takes a backseat, but Kanna joins in, including a bunch of other characters. That's fun. I like this story. It's charming and cute. I would love to give the story a 8, but the ending is a bit of a letdown in comparison with the other episodes.


Art: 9/10

The art is really good. The character models look good, the colors are nice and the body animations are fluid. But where this anime really shines are the fight scenes. Yes, fight scenes. This show has some wicked fight scenes. They are very few of them and they are always really brief, but when they happen it's like a christmas. Plus, the fight scenes are visually a nice contrast to the simple and calm artstyle.


Music 8/10  

The music is good. I especially love the OP. While not my favorite, it's still really good.


Character: 9/10

The characters are the best part of the anime. Kobayashi is down to earth alcoholist, Tohru is a happy lesbian who wants to do everything to make Kobayashi happy, Kanna is a cute dragon loli who is actually the FBI in disguise, Lucoa is a… *cough* good looking dragon who is pretty quiet, Fafnir is a shadow the hedgehog ripoff who wishes death on all humans but sticks around for the video games and Elma has a obsession with food. The only complaint I have with the characters is that Elma is really underused. She showed that she has a pretty funny personality, but that is shoved away for a obsession with food joke that gets tiring after a while. But this is still my favorite cast of characters and (saying it again) the best part of this anime.  


Enjoyment: 10/10  

The excellent cast and the interactions between them gave me back then a sort of vibe that reminded me of the vibe I got watching cartoon shows when I still was in primary school. This vibe is pretty nostalgic, so I was surprised I got that vibe from a media I had never consumed before. I didn't have that vibe since, which makes this anime even more special. This vibe including the amount of charm in this show has and the genuinely funny comedy resulted in a experience that I will never forget. Made In Abyss maybe made me almost cry and One Punch Man maybe made me laugh my ass off, Kobayashi's Maid Dragon made me smile.  


Overall: 9/10  

I would absolutely recommend it if you want to watch a show that makes you smile.

Overall - 8:
The art and characters are fantastic, and the way the story is set up leads to some good comedy. There is a lot of the same joke, and not everything makes perfect sense, but it's a good watch if you're looking for a light hearted anime with some unique character dynamics.
Story - 6:
The story setup is pretty simple, but there are times I feel like they tried to explain more things about the world, and it didn't turn out all that good. They also felt the need to make the final episodes be climactic, which I feel took away from the story insome ways.


The episode to episode stuff is what the focus is, and I'm glad it is. This anime feels like a harem anime that didn't quite pan out, but in a good way. It has a lot of the set up, many characters with unique traits to appeal to the viewers, the capacity for lots of fanservice, and (some) of the characters living with the protagonist. The difference here is that instead of introducing as many characters as possible, the anime sticks to a small cast of about 9. In addition to that not all the characters are romantically attracted to the protagonist, and to top it all of the main character is female.


So instead of having a very formulaic structure of introducing characters and focusing on the antics that come from them all pursuing the same person, there is friendship and comradery.


Art - 9:

In addition to having a great and colorful style, the animation quality is tops. They don't use the excuse of the genre not being action to save time or effort here, and the couple of action scenes it does have are beautiful.


Sound - 6:

The OSTs are nothing special, the voice acting and sound effects are fair.


Character - 9:

The characters are the major appeal of this series, and every one the major cast are amazing in their own regard. Kobayashi is an amazing person, and it's great to see how she changes, and how others notice these changes throughout the series. Fafnir and Makoto's relationship is one of my favorite I've seen in recent times, and watching Shota and lucoa's interactions is always entertaining. Lucoa in general is not only a great character for fanservice, but a very kind and sensible character as well.


Enjoyment - 8:

I personally tend to enjoy anime with a heavy focus on the overall story and action/drama more than most of the more lighthearted romance and comedies anime out there. That being said, this anime had me laughing, loving, and wanting to watch more, so as far as slice-of-lifes go it's pretty darn good.

Kobayashi-san Chi no Maid Dragon reemphasizes the themes of friendship and belonging as it charms its audience with cuteness. From the author, Cool Kyoushinsha, and the studio, Kyoto Animation, Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid is a slice of life anime that can definitely brighten up anyone’s day through its heart-filled story and lovable characters. Even though it has elements and characters that come from the fantastic, the anime’s story encourages people to reflect upon their own friendships and gauge their belonging with others. With its fluid animation and vivid art style, this anime creates a world which has a level of realism that mirrors reality but stillhas a cartoonish style that adds a subtle fantasy atmosphere. The voice acting and music of Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid also establishes a friendly and playful tone in every episode, nicely embellishing the anime as a whole. As a result of this anime’s elements, Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid is a slice of life anime that proves to be an enjoyable and meaningful watch.


Regarding the story, Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid portrays a slice of life story that follows the daily life of the character, Miss Kobayashi, and the dragons that she lives and interacts with. But, even though this anime does have its light-hearted moments, Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid revolves around Miss Kobayashi’s and Tohru’s struggle to accept each other and each other’s worlds. The dragon maid, Tohru, is an outlier of society who wants to fit in and the human, Miss Kobayashi, is the vessel through which she can learn how to fit into and live in the world. The same could be said about Miss Kobayashi who must also learn how to live in her changed world. Thus, in order to resolve this alien versus the norm conflict, the anime’s heartwarming moments not only charms the audience, but also propels the growth of the characters’ relationships. To compliment these heart-filled moments, there are several gags in this anime that lighten up the mood, showing the comedy of the abnormal living with the norm. This combination of comedy and heartwarming scenes illustrates the development of relationships from inclusion to affection, reemphasizing the idea that anyone can befriend someone who is completely different from herself. To evaluate, although this anime is indeed a simple slice of life story, its themes of friendship and belonging give the anime even more meaning.


With respect to the characters and their development, Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid introduces several memorable characters that add cuteness and fun to the anime. The introduction of other dragons such as Kanna, Lucoa, Fafnir, and Elma eases Tohru’s conflict of fitting into Kobayashi’s world. Bringing attention to the main human character, Miss Kobayashi, even though her character is plain at first, her development throughout the anime is significant. Miss Kobayashi’s development from a serious, closed-minded character to a happy, open-minded character demonstrates how Tohru and the dragons have significantly impacted her life. Similarly, Tohru also develops her trust for the humans and gains knowledge of where she belongs in Kobayashi's world. But, her character does not develop as much as Miss Kobayashi because of her loyalty as a maid to Miss Kobayashi. Summing up, the characters of Kobayashi's Dragon Maid liven up the anime's atmosphere and are very memorable.


In terms of art and animation, Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid executes its story well with vivid art and animation. This anime’s art style is indeed cartoonish, but it still captures the essence of reality in such way that makes the characters and settings seem real. The vivid animation also upholds a lively, cartoonish mood but still maintains some level of realism. In other words, the animation pays great attention to the practical movements of reality, remarkably displaying the beauty of each character’s motions.


In order to absorb the audience into the anime even more, Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid’s voice acting and soundtrack embellish the story and animation, giving life to the anime as a whole. The choice of cast for the anime is well done and accurately portrays the characters’ attitudes and personalities. The music also adds to the overall atmosphere of this anime. From playful and cute tunes to serious and heartwarming melodies, the anime’s soundtrack greatly enhances the overall feel of the anime, making every scene even more memorable. 


Thus, from anyone who wants to relax to someone who wants some enlightenment, Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid both warms the heart and expands upon themes to think about. The anime’s cuteness will have audience members hooked into a story that may seem simple, but has a hidden depth to it. But, there are indeed other themes other than friendship and belonging that this anime explores. So, it is up to the viewer to find them or just sit back and enjoy a fluffy anime. To conclude, this anime is a well done slice of life anime that anyone can enjoy.


But, the decision to watch this anime is entirely up to you. I acknowledge and respect all opinions about this anime and I hope that you'll read my reviews in the future!
