----------
Disclaimer
----------
The following review is completely spoiler-free, and is meant for users who are curious about whether to watch the show or not. While I write reviews with this focus, and the goal of presenting the show with little bias, it is impossible to write a completely unbiased review. Feel free to disagree with any of my opinions, and ultimately decide for yourself how you feel about the show after watching it yourself!
---------
Positives
---------
- Colourful Character Design
One of the things that attracted me to this show is its over-the-top, sensational character designs. The dragons are all wonderful to look at, and enjoyable in their uniqueness. Their traitsand specialities shine on screen, helping keep them the focal point of the show (for good reason).


- Beautiful Art Direction

This show has absolutely wonderful art! Its backgrounds are unique in their water-colour approach, and provide a very pretty light background to many large environment shots. They also do not feel out of place or forced, but rather give off a relative serenity to be associated with the outside world juxtaposing the characters.


- Surprisingly Diverse Animation

I can't believe a Slice of Life show like this was able to pull off some of the action sequences it did so well. Any over-the-top sequence the dragons took part in (and there were many) were accentuated by a shockingly well done set of action animations. It perfectly conveyed the actual power of the dragons, and made those scenes absolutely pop out compared to the day-to-day scenes, which is exactly what they were supposed to do.


- Kanna

Kanna the tiny dragon child is aboslutely adorable. I don't think I've ever smiled and said "AWWW" so loudly or so often at an anime. Ever. Perfect example of children characters not needing to be overly annoying to still be important and cute in anime. 10/10 would watch entire side-series about her.


- Heartwarming Moments

The interactions between the small makeshift family of Kobayashi, Tohru, and Kanna provide some incredibly heartwarming moments along the way. While the show's main focus is clearly light hearted slice of life and comedy, the show never forgets to gracefully tug at the viewer's heartstrings, investing us all in the family dynamic (flaws and all).


- OP/ED

Probably my personal favourite OP of all time (so catchy), along with a very well done ED. Both match the mood of the show very well (starting on a high note, ending more calmly and sweetly). The inclusion of the show's characters in the ED song is also a huge bonus from me!


---------

Negatives

---------

- Lucoa's Lack of Depth

The character Quetzalcoatl, or Lucoa for short, begins the series as an interesting counterpart dragon to the rest. She comes off as a bit strange in busty appearance, but ultimately caring in her part-time role as Tohru's friend. Her guidance early on was a perfectly good character trait for her. However, later in the show she constantly boils down to either needing another dragon that isn't Fafnir, or full-on no thought boob humour. Don't get me wrong, I love sexual humour! But there was not a whole lot of "comedy" in how she was used in the show. This is an example of fanservice done badly.


- Shouta's Inclusion

Shouta as a character himself could be perfectly fine. He himself does nothing particularly wrong, and introducing magical beings other than dragons could provide a very interesting dynamic. However, none of that is explored as Shouta's one goal is to be the target of Lucoa's overt sexuality. Every single scene with him in it is either completely unnecessary to have him around, or it involves him running away from Lucoa's sexual advances. This could have been fine had the show decided to make her advances based on misunderstanding (she doesn't know why he's shy/embarrassed around her; He's intimidated by her overt sexuality), but instead it just comes off as creepy and unnecessary. There is one singular funny and unique moment for the duo in the show, but otherwise provide no additional value in my opinion.


- "The Scene"

There is a scene about halfway through the show between Kanna and a human her age that has been well documented in its ridiculousness. I will not spoil anything related to it (you can do that research on your own), but I personally was a bit shocked at how far it went and how it pushed the boundaries. I don't think the idea was a ridiculous one; There was much comedy to be had in the circumstances. But in my opinion they went a bit too far in their pursuit for sexual humour, and if I had the choice I'd cut it a lot short than it was.


- Kobayashi + Tohru Character Interaction

Many interactions between characters are incredibly well done and thought out, however arguably the biggest relationship of the entire show progresses at an absolutely sluggish pace. Kobayashi talks a good game about how things have changed dramatically, however it takes until the final few episodes before those words become visible actions and finally provide satisfying character progress between the two main characters. For a show that does such a good job with its other character progressions (Fafnir and Kanna as two examples), this one was slightly disappointing.


----------

Conclusion

----------

Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid is a spectacularly made show let down by a few small gripes. It impressed me extraordinarily with its charm, its character design, its art, and many more aspects, all of which I would rate almost perfect. 


Unfortunately for the show, it has a few weak points (mentioned above) that can be really crippling at times. Luckily, these weak points are far in the minority, so overall the show was still incredibly enjoyable and fun to watch. You can't make a memorable show without flying too close to the sun sometimes, so I won't fault it for trying a bunch of interesting ideas (most of which worked out). 


The show otherwise shines brighter than many other shows I've seen, and while it might seem to stand out solely based on the whole "dragon gimmick", I can assure you that it is far from the only thing that makes this show stand out.


------------

Final Rating

------------

While it makes for nice averages and wonderful sorting, when it comes to reviews I personally do not like direct numbering systems. Instead, I am to answer the question: "Would you recommend I watch this show?".


If you are a fan of slice of life, light comedy, cute dragons, or having your heart melt in various different ways, this is a show you will not want to miss.


If you find any kind of sexualization around unambiguously child-like characters unacceptable, there will be parts of this show that you will not like (as was the case with me). I would still recommend giving it a shot (as did I), as it is otherwise a tremendous product.

Hey folks, this will be a review for Kobayashi-san Chi no Maid Dragon. Honestly I was disappointed. The reviews and Gifs of this show made this out to be far more enjoyable than it actually was.
The story revolves around a dragon named Tooru, and her friend/savior Kobayashi. The start of the show we are introduced to both in a comical and crazy way. It appears to open into a slice of life show, with comical undertones with dragons learning the ways of humans. It also had some "deeper" connotations which might have been good if they kept feeding it to us like the first fewepisodes. However after about three episodes the show stops being about dragons and humans and becomes just about humans. The "deeper" moments also stop being dished out well, and are instead piled on at the end of the episodes like some cheap dressing. 


The art was very pretty and well done, the soundtrack was really enjoyable as well. This is easily the best part of the show.


The characters start off interesting as well. Tooru is a dragon that can bring about Armageddon and has decided to live as a maid in Kobayashi's home. This is extra fun because she doesn't know what a maid is, in fact when asked she starts handing out pamphlets like you see in front of maid cafes. Kobayashi is basically a nerdy programmer girl who doesn't have anyone in her life outside of a co worker who also shares interests in maids. The clash of the hyper dragon and the "old woman" character in Kobayashi makes for some decent comedy and interesting setting.


A few episodes into the show they introduce a few other dragons. Each dragon has a strong and vibrant personality and you can expect some hi jinks to happen. However once introductions are finished and the show becomes melodrama and loses all interesting characteristics. The dragon's integrating with humans stops being an issue until the last two episodes where in they do the typical cheesy dialogue happy ending. I mean why even bother making them dragons, it didn't add anything to the show. In fact the angle they are trying to take with the drama would have been easier to achieve with an orphan or a runaway. 


Overall I have to say I disliked the show. It took me a while to complete it because of the ending drama always killing my enthusiasm for the next episode. The show starts off unique and fun and turns into a mess because it tries to become two different things, and doesn't manage becoming either of them. For those of you looking for humor and cute scenes, there are a few but it doesn't deliver them as well as many shows in that genre. for those of you looking for an emotional show with decent dialogue and weighty scenes, it doesn't give you those. Honestly I would not recommend this show to people who are not fans of slice of life shows.


TLDR: Not great. Theme switches early and becomes an episodic formula which is frankly boring. Usage of dragons doesn't seem to matter. Art and sound both fantastic, check out the soundtrack.

Kyoto Animation produced this, which is fitting because this is a titillating moe time-waster, and if you want one of those polished to a mirror finish, accept no substitutes. You could stop the review there and score it a 4 or something, but this titillating moe time-waster has some of the most side-splittingly funny gags in comedy anime, and solid heartwarming themes of family and companionship that echo back to the Clannad series.
The flair for the ridiculous is almost like the manga author took a few pages out of Nichijou's book. "OK, gotta go to work, and... uh, there's a dragon outside my door. Andshe turned into a maid with a tail and horns." There was maybe one episode (the skit) where the comedy was mostly lost on me.


I like comedies where a character might seem like an evil villain but ultimately she's harmless, and with seemingly one exception Kobayashi-san's characters fill that bill. You see the full range of KyoAni's abilities when the dragons duke it out even at partial power, and watching them tone it down to "Kobayashi's standard" is a great running gag.


It's not all raucous humor and boob jokes (and while there are several of the latter, this isn't High School DxD or Qwaser)-- Kobayashi talking the dragons into accepting modern Japanese society is the true power of this show. Kobayashi, of course, isn't exactly a model example of a head of household or anything, but she has a strong heart and is able to think on her feet. You really don't see that kind of woman character very often.


The show's weakness is story, as is the case with many shows like this. Most of the time it's "Story? What story?" until the final 2 episodes or so ("Oh, right, that story!"). Generally I don't consider this that much of a weakness in comedy, because usually I'm too busy laughing to care. It's like a Monty Python or a good SNL sketch.


In conclusion, I can watch Kanna pop her tail out of an electrical outlet all day.

Bless KyoAni for this cute masterpiece~!
Put bluntly, Kobayashi-san Chi no Maid Dragon did not exactly have a great story (although the story was linear and quite easy to follow) considering the fact that it's a slice-of-life anime. Nonetheless, the show truly deserves all the praise that it can get and more.
The art and animation (as expected of Kyoto Animation) is truly eye candy. The sounds and music (especially the opening) really stick to you and that's a good sign; it simply means that the songs are catchy and it livens up the atmosphere. Basically, upon hearing the opening, you'd instantly know that what's coming upis going to be an explosion of moe and all the cutesies and cuddlies.


The characters are amazing and lovable. Kobayashi's character development, specifically, is the cream of it all. I loved how she started off a loner and was living everyday life like a normal office person, but suddenly and abruptly changes forever because of this sweet and beautiful dragon girl. It's pretty simple if you think about it, but it's not the simplicity of it that matters. What matters is that you (as the audience) know how the characters felt and how they changed for the better. I think that is beautiful in itself.


Overall, it's utterly adorable and enjoyable! (Points for Kanna-chan! She's unarguably the most curious, sweetest, and cutest character of this past season.)

So everyone is writing about Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid, so I thought, I may as well write about it.
Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid is not a comedy anime, nor it tries to be. Don’t be fooled by that comedy tag because it is not a comedy anime in any sense and If it is a comedy anime then it is pretty bad one. It is a moe-slice of life anime. So, what makes it tick?
Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid works on two planes, first are characters and other is setting. It is an anime about characters interacting with the setting, which is not a new idea persay, everyone uses it but let us see how it works in Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid.


Now as an anime Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid has nothing standing for it. It doesn’t have a story, it doesn’t have unique characters or does it have good world building for fantasy anime, but what it has is a unique premise on the paper at least and Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid uses its premise to its fullest. The show asks a simple thing. You have a maid dragon, right? then use her dragoness to its fullest. It doesn’t hold back using its uniqueness in its premise, it doesn’t drive towards normal but use it differentness in it highest possible capacity. That is why Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid stands out of all other “unique” anime that came before it. There is no lack of “unique” anime but the lack of using that unique to it fullest.


Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid doesn’t shy away to mix and experiment. It mixes the genre so well that you couldn’t even tell what genre is Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid is, except the slice of life. Driving the show was a slice of life, a comedy with heavy yaoi undertones without any seriousness which I loved. Normally this subject is shipped with a huge baggage of seriousness but not here. While the tone of the show remains consistent but the last episode had a completely different tone that it felt like completely different anime altogether and that is saying something. It is not normal for anime to change its tone this way, but it gives us a very satisfying ending which could not have done otherwise. Which just say how experimenting this anime is.


As I said that Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid is all about how characters interact with the setting(nearly everything is about that anyway). Anime provides very generic characters with generic traits but there is a difference that they are all dragons and because they are dragons they become unique characters. Even when they have generic trait they think different than a human, they are different than humans in every aspect of their thinking. You can see this from their day to day life with their human counterparts. Show simply take these generic dragon characters and puts them in human environment to see what happens, Which is the main appeal of Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid.


Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid is a simple anime about a cute human looking maid with dragons mind doing maid works in a dragon way.

Exactly what it looks like: otkau-bait, moe, generic medieval fantasy, and maids.  But it's so fun to watch!
The show's not going to change your world, it's not going to surprise you, but it's going to entertain you.  Nice characters do cute things and live together.  Beings from another world don't understand our Earth customs.  People who seem different find strange reasons to be friends, and people who seem like they're cut from the same mold find a reason to be friends that you didn't expect.
When the world is more cynical and scared than ever before, when we're retreating behind our nationalborders, that's when we need shows like this to remind us that strange friendships are waiting for us, out there somewhere.  Shows that remind us that the best thing in the world is other people, even if--like Kobayashi--we aren't the best at expressing how we feel.


The good--it's pure unadulterated fun.  The OP and ED are fantastic (the OP is stupidly good).  The power of friendship.  The way Kobayashi is presented--someone who's suddenly realized that they're a serious adult, kind but not good at expressing it, mature in some ways but at other times not really prepared to be an adult.  Then again, maybe I just relate to her because I'm the same age, have the same job, living the same life, and have the same problems.


The bad--predictable.  The lesbian schoolgirl Rika and the oversexualized Quetzalcoatl are a bit too much, especially Quetzalcoatl.  If I never see another anime where characters have a conversation about breast size it wouldn't be too soon.


Other notes--The final episode tries to extract a climax out of the source material, which works better than you'd expect.  It gives the series a good note to end on even though the series doesn't need a climax.


So if you're looking for a pick-me-up in a world that seems a little too real, or a bit of fun after a long day of Python web development like Kobayashi, maybe thirteen episodes with a dragon maid are exactly what you need.

Chores. We all hate them. A part of our everyday lives, it takes us away from what we really want to do. We can't enjoy ourselves to the fullest because we are forced to look after ourselves and anyone else that lives with us. But what if we got a maid? Not just any old maid, but a dragon maid?
Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid is the story of how a dragon named Tohru was saved by Kobayashi, your everyday office worker. Feeling indebted to Kobayashi, Tohru becomes her maid, but the title kinda explains this already sothere wasn't really any use saying it all over again. The show simply follows the life of Kobayashi and Tohru as they try and adjust to their new life. With a few more dragons popping up, we watch as they all try to fit into the everyday lives of humans.


It's a pretty simple Slice of Life, each episode looking at the daily lives of Kobayashi and the other dragons. Usually, there is one big story per episode with a few gag scenes thrown in as transitions. It's quite a nice formula, and it allows for all the characters to get plenty of screen time throughout the series. The story doesn't really progress into anything until the final episodes, so it's really just a look at the antics of each character, which is where most of the comedy comes from, with a healthy dose of world building around the dragon's home.


There's no real concrete formula for its comedy, as it changes its jokes a lot, only repeating a select few. It mainly focuses on the character roster and their interactions with humans and their environment. It's incredibly funny with the way it executes each joke, which is mostly unexpected excluding the few that get repeated a lot. At times it can also get quite serious, with important issues like the negative effects dragon's might have on the human world, but it doesn't force it into unneeded drama that loses its original meaning. Simply having it brought up allows us, as viewers, to think about it as well, creating a much bigger impact on us then forced drama would have done.


Kobayashi is as normal as you get, except for her weird obsession with maids and butlers, but other than that she's pretty normal. You might assume that her personality might be boring, but it provides a wonderful contrast against the absurdity of dragons. She's basically a personification of how we would react if we were placed in the same situation. Her inner monologues also provide us with a look into character, thinking about how her life has been impacted by her new friends. It's so nice that the main character isn't some pussy teenage boy that we usually get with these group of supernatural characters anime.


Dragon Spoilers


The dragons are all great with their defining personalities. From the maid to the loli, each one seems to fall into a stereotype, but it proves us wrong as we get a deeper look into each character. Tohru worries about how long she'll be able to stay with Kobayashi, Kanna has family issues, Fafnir hates humans but decides to live with one, Quetzalcoatl (or Lucoa for short) is a fallen goddess, and Elma is technically the enemy. Instead of dwelling on these issues, it just gives a sense of personality and realism to most of these dragons, preventing them from being boring background characters. There are a few that just end up being part of the cast for the sake of having more characters, and the fanservice with some characters can get a little overbearing, so keep that in mind


End of Dragon Spoilers


What little drama is brought up focuses on Tohru's main issue, and it's done so well that instead of feeling forced it's actually quite heartwarming. Most Slice of Life animes end up created drama so it has a conclusive ending, usually ruining the show in the process, but Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid does it so well that it just slides in as just another episode, albeit a little emotional.


Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid just does everything so well. The comedy, characters, drama, it just fits together so perfectly that there are almost no faults in the series. I recommend it to everyone that wants a Slice of Life that's a little different from the rest.

Maid Dragon is a competently executed comedy/slice of life punctuated by standout moments of animated razzle dazzle. The show is, on the whole, pretty alright. 
Unfortunately, that's the show's biggest  sin. It's pretty alright... and that's about it.
This is an interesting counterpoint to another show from this past winter season, Kemono Friends, the low budget, abominably animated children's program about zoo animals turned into anthropomorphic girls. Where that show lacked in terms of flourish, Maid Dragon shines with aplomb. Granted, this is a KyoAni show, a certain level of visual fidelity is a given, but man is this show pretty. Despite the played-for-comedy mundanityof the premise, there are some sequences here that are just gorgeous. It's as if the studio is just showing off: a scene where two dragons play fight has visuals that could rival film productions. Throw in an OP/ED wombo combo of catchiness and you've got a show that excels aesthetically.


That's all surface level, though. A show like Kemono Friends drew in viewers because it had heart; it oozes with a passion that's endearing and infectious. Maid Dragon, on the other hand, feels a bit more hollow and thin. I wouldn't say the show is soulless, but it's thinner than a communion wafer and less fulfilling on both a spiritual and carnal level.


The eponymous Kobayashi and Tohru are decent as vehicles for the premise, Kanna's cute, Lucoa is best girl, and Fafnir is Jotaro Kujo as a NEET power gamer shut in dragon, which I appreciate, but there's not much to them beyond that. Elma is added late and leaves little impression. Saikawa and Shouta have one joke that gets repeated over... and over... and over again, without much in the way of subversion or wit.


I don't even mind the subject matter of the jokes (grade school lesbians and /ss/), but at least give me a little variety.


It's not even that the jokes are all bad or that I never laughed, a few really good setups found their way in, but it's all pretty predictable after a certain point. The show makes a few attempts at pathos and while it's appreciated, it never feels like the characters have much room to grow after the first few episodes. It's a shame, too, because a show like K-On! shows that the studio is clearly capable of making something meaningful out of a SOL premise, but they just didn't bother here. Maybe they didn't try.


For all the effort that went into the look of the show, everything else fell by the wayside. This isn't to say that Maid Dragon is bad, but it's only serviceable. KyoAni hit all the notes it had to and not a single note more. Maid Dragon is a decent watch as long as it's on, but there's nothing to think about or chew over after the credits have rolled. I won't say don't watch it, but this is the sort of program you save for when you have time to kill and you want something light, breezy, and ultimately insubstantial. 


At the end of the day, for better or worse, Maid Dragon is filler for life. If that's what you're looking for, you could do worse. After all, it's pretty alright.

This is a hard review to write because I want to be objective but at the same time I absolutely love this series so much that it's difficult to remain impartial. I will do my best. There are spoilers below, so...do what you will.
Kobayashi is by far the character I can most relate to in all of anime/manga. As someone who has slaved away for the past 30 years in the high tech industry and never ventured very far out of my introverted shell, I am Kobayashi. And the thing that is really underappreciated about Kobayashi's character is that it's not that she particularly lovesher job or feels that she's changing the world through her work - it's just that work is all she has. That's it. She's good at her job, people rely on her, but that is her entire life. For anyone out there that is really good at their job and spends all their time working because they're not good at anything else, you can relate, right? 


The later episode that goes into more detail on the night Kobayashi meets Tooru in the woods actually brought a tear to my eye. Not because it was touching, but because of the way Kobayashi is mistreated by her boss, works herself to death to shut him up, then goes out and gets completely wasted by herself to numb the pain. She's so wasted she thinks it's funny that she misses her train stop and gets lost in the middle of nowhere, not because it's actually funny, but because at that point there's nothing she can do but laugh at how sad her life is. And, hey! May as well buy another giant bottle of sake and go wander home by herself, right! I have been there many times. 


Kobayashi's loneliness is pretty much incurable because she doesn't know how to relate to other people. She *would* like to have friends and family relationships but just can't bring herself to open herself up to it. This is her primary internal conflict: she both wants and simulteaneously abhors relationships with others. So she just does nothing but work, and work, and work.


Tooru is conflicted in a similar way. As a dragon in the "other world" she hates humans as her mortal enemy. However, in reality she is a kind-hearted dragon deep down inside. But for all her power, she is also incapable of obtaining the one thing she desires with all her heart - a loving relationship. When she meets Kobayashi, Tooru recognizes that Kobayashi needs someone, and decides that someone is her. If I have any advice for the introverted, lonely people out there - find someone that loves you the the way that Tooru loves Kobayashi. 


Watching Kobayashi's transformation over the series is absolutely heart-warming. I was literally choking up in SPOILERS the episode where Kanna asks her to come to sports day. Kobayashi is initially resistant because sports day falls on a work deadline, but seeing Kanna's disappointment she decides to work extra hard to finish early so she can be there for Kanna. The other episode that really tugs at the heart strings is the one where the dragons and kids put on the holiday show for the folks at the old folks home. Kobayashi is initially worried the dragons are overdoing it, but by the end she is just as enchanted as the rest of the audience. When Kobayashi pets Tooru on the head and praises her for doing a good job without Tooru having to ask first - it's a nut punch in the feels.


And if your heart doesn't absolutely melt when you see Kobayashi fighting a giant scary dragon over whether Torru stays with her or goes back, you really need to take a deep look inside the dark empty husk of a human you are to see if you have any feelings at all. Side note: I was so happy to see the OAV with the scene where Torru confesses her love for Kobayashi, and Kobayashi accepts....so adorable. "Shall we breed now" is my new catchphrase.


At times hilarious, heart-breaking, and touching with a worthy cast of supporting characters - of course Kanna is everyone's favorite, but the rest of the dragons are fun to watch.


Spectacularly animated, voice acting on point, well-written beyond belief, and the deep dives into the lives of dragons make this a can't miss series. 


[edit] by the way, for all the reviews hating on this because the way the relationships are depicted between adults and children - it's a parody of these tropes, people. It is not dramatized unironically. If you take these things literally, you are the butt of the joke...

Tooru is a dragon maid. Let that sink in for a moment. She is a maid who is also a dragon. It's in the title. It's brought up in the first episode. And then... it honestly rarely comes up that much again except for rehashing the same old gags. Miss Kobayashi-san Chi no Maid Dragon is a comedy, slice of life, fantasy anime that aired in Winter 2017 from Jan 12 2017 to April 6th 2017. To quickly sum up the show, we follow the life of Kobayashi who is an female working adult who is now living with Tohru, a dragon now a maid for Kobayashi herself. Hence the show’s title. My initial impression of the anime was very low as I expected it to be a harem with all these female characters andheaps of fanservice. How very wrong I was. I loved this anime. I think what this anime executed very well was the sense of family and friendship like no other. This is especially true with Tohru and Kobayashi. The relationship between these characters is evolving throughout the anime was a pleasure to watch as well as the relationship with another character called Kanna. Kanna has a daughter to mother relationship with Kobayashi and sister-sister to Tohru, even though she is also a dragon too with no relation to either of these characters by blood. While people say that you can only get unconditional love from your parents, I feel that this anime proves as testament against that fact. The opening song for the anime is lovely to listen to and full of life which just symbolises everything about the anime. The animation is excellent. It’s colourful and bright and the art style really appeals to me especially with the fantasy elements in the anime. 


Another theme that this anime explores is understanding that while every person is different to one another, we can still respect each other’s morals,values and perspective on the world. We can still love one another as for what we are and not change ourselves just because we are told to but because we want to. This is evident with Tohru’s transition from a dragon to a human and living with Kobayashi. This theme is recurring in the anime quite a lot especially when we are looking at this from Tohru and Kobayashi’s perspectives or just the interaction between the two characters.

Kyoto Animation really hit the nail in the head with the characters. Firstly, Kobayashi the working adult without any happiness in her life except the monotonous cycle of her programming job. Tohru, the dragon-maid trying to find a purpose in this new world after leaving hers. Kanna, a dragon who is essentially a child needing love for which she didn’t get. Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid has easily been the most surprising series all around. From episode 1 I was hooked, and now that the series is over, I am very sad. You see, if I’m being honest here, this is one of the first new anime I’ve loved, truly loved since… I wanna say Attack on Titan which came out in 2013. Now I do want to say that this series may not be as good as a lot of anime out these days, but the fact that for me it came out of nowhere and told an incredible funny, entertaining, lighthearted story in just ashort 13 episodes. So thank you once again to Megumin for recommending me this anime in the first place.


Story


The fact this anime exists and has the plot it has, the characters, the art style while telling a somewhat deep story about people who are in this fantasy world where dragons can go to and fro from their world and the humans realm, well that’s an accomplishment, one that should never be forgotten. It got me to care about Kobayashi, a boring human character in a series full of colorful, cute, magical and destructive dragons. And it also got me to care more or less about most of the dragons that only have a minor role in the series, for example the series has these two secondary characters with no real worth to the main story line, Kanna and Elma. Now they both have their own kind of storylines if you can call them that, but they’re for the most part segregated to one role. And these roles are more or less there to at most just help the story move forward. Normally these are characters I don’t care about, Why? Because they usually have no personality outside of the generic, basic one. An example of this in something popular is Chiaotzu from Dragon Ball Z, the little guy is completely useless and has no character, and because of that I have no real connection to that character. But this series makes me care about Elma and Kanna, and Elma is featured even less than Kanna is, to the point of where I question her role, and honestly can’t remember if she had one, which is a gripe of these secondary character too, they have no meaningful use in the series. But we’ll get into that in a moment, back to my point, Kanna and Elma, and even the whole weird Quetzalcoatl and Shuto thing, I care about it, which is hard for me to say about some things these day, especially slice of life series filled with cute dragon girls. 



As I was saying before, the secondary characters seem to have no use. Quetzalcoatl is the absolutely most useless and questionable addition to the cast, and the same goes for Elma. Now their parts are funny, and they’re adorable segments sometimes, but what really is the point I ask myself, as a writer, I could have found ways to get these scenes in with less characters and make more sense in some points. Now this is really nitpick, as it works for the show, but it felt like a kind of Prometheus syndrome kind of moment, where in the moment it was great, but you think about it for a minute and it felt unnecessary. This is probably the one major thing I found from this series that I found as a problem. And even then, it really won’t harm your viewing experience, and it shouldn't, the show is written well enough to let you not think about these things until after viewing. 


Next up I want to talk about how great the story is in just 13 episodes. The whole series is simple, and has a story that feel genuine and real even though… it’s an anime. I can’t tell you how many times I’ve watched an anime like this, as it’s not often I do, especially anime involving tropes like this. It’s just a well made anime from top to bottom. The things I most enjoy about it has to be the characters interactions with each other. It feels natural for the series, and in no way shape or form does it feel like it’s a chore to see these characters interact. I enjoyed Elma interacting with Kobayashi while Tohru didn’t exactly like them interacting too much. I also licked how, for some reason, there was this recurring joke that Tohru wanted Kobayashi to eat her tail. It was just a little bit of dark comedy, but I found it blended well with the show in every way. Of course Tohru would want to do that, she’s Tohru. You have moments like these in the show a lot, which is a testament to how well the characters are written. After they’re introduced we simply just know who and what they are, and that’s a side effect of using tropes and archetypes to your advantage. I like to use this test, would I want a poster of, let’s say Tohru on my wall. If I do, then that means the series has captured not only my money, but my interest and shows they wrote a character well. And yeah, I’d totally put up a poster of Tohru on my wall.


Animation


Probably some of the best animation I’ve seen this whole year, and we’re not even halfway through it. Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid has easily the most accessible art direction of an anime I’ve seen this year. It’s fun, it’s bright, it’s colorful and it’s cute. You can’t tell me Kobayashi isn’t a cool design for a character that fits her personality and harkens back to a different time in anime. And I also feel the designs for the dragons are great as well, including both versions of their human forms. But also the human character are good too, I think you can’t count that them out. The show basically just goes over the top with character designs and it works for every character. The reason is because the show is ridiculous fun from top to bottom. 


Alright let’s not forget about something else that a lot of people noticed. The awesome ass animation for the fighting scene! How could anyone forget? They’re easily the best the show has animation wise, it’s epic. In fact, I think it’s so good that I wouldn’t be mad if they made a spinoff series where Dragon girls fight each other, and specifically Dragon girls, because Dragons fighting are cool, but the animation doesn’t make their Dragon forms stand-out too much in battle for me. I think the human forms for the Dragon girls are the way to go in a series like that. It’s just really well animated in this portions of the show and a lot of people agree with me they want a show using this same art style and animation team making awesome fight scenes against Tohru and Kanna.


English Dub


I’m just going to say this now, I think the English Dub is 100% better than the Japanese Dub. The voices in the english version capture the Japanese version completely, and the only time I don’t see that is the voice actors for Quetz, but even then it’s still an amazing actor voicing her. Other than that, Tohru, Kanna and Kobayashi are casted perfectly, they match the tone and inflection to the original Japanese version, and I think make improvements on it. Not some of you may disagree with that statement, but I feel that the shows comedy helps make that happen. It’s comedy that American to British audiences and understand and enjoy, so when they go to voice act it, it feels natural and easy. There aren't a lot of puns, there isn’t a lot of culture shock involved in the script. Because of this I think it’s in my top 10 of English Dubs ever, and I am very confident in saying that.


Score


The score for Dragon Maid is also pretty solid, probably not a soundtrack you’d buy and OST for, at least for me. But I think personally it's a score that compliments the comedy really well. I noticed it a couple times specifically during the Sport Themed episode, which was amazing anyways, but the score there really sold some moments for me. Also another great episode is I think the episode where I think Kanna and Tohru fight each other in an epic battle that rivals some Dragon Ball Z episodes. The score in that episode really sold how powerful these Dragons are, and how they can destroy anything in seconds. 


Final Rating


Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid is easily the best anime of the season, and will go down as one of the funniest and cute shows of the year. The animation is perfect, the score is great, and the English Dub is the best I’ve seem in a long time, rivaling some of the best dubs out there. But the show really glows when it comes to the story and the characters, making the audience care for super powerful Dragons that could easily destroy anything. Even when there is no main villain or goal, it creates characters you root for and want to see succeed. Miss Kobayashi’s Dragon Maid is an example of masterful execution of an anime.

I am very late in reviewing this animation mainly because I had only heard about it from a random source and thought nothing of it at first. I am not normally a person who watches anime (animations out of artistic respect and courtesy) although I have watched plenty as a child. Now grown up I have become more picky and selective with my time and being a huge gamer, college student and worker I almost never watch shows anymore save for a few. So it speaks volumes that as an "outsider" I can say this show was one of the best and unexpected surprises forme in a long time.


It's the daily sitcom style that many attribute as "slice of life" that focuses more on the characters instead of the plot. While this already can be a dealbreaker for some, the characters (mostly) keep the show great and increasing in emotion as it leads to a finale so much so that I think it's almost a none issue. The dragons that act as humans in a modern setting is a clear sort of parody to the quirky and odd that animation seems so engraved to have in that it almost doesn't work for the show. There is some sexual stuff that happens (not all in good taste) and some moments don't shine as they should, but the majority of the time there is so much energy and spirit put into the main characters like Tohru, Kobayashi and Kanna that I was sold by episode 2 for the whole series.


As a critic for games and films, I tend to see animation on a art level that can give the viewer some sort of message to take away from, regardless of how unrealistic it could be. With dragons as women and men with all sorts of vibrancy that screams "been there, done that" with countless shows before it, it's honestly refreshing to see this energetic cast take off to keep my attention. The pacing can sometimes be a bit too fast for jokes to land a hit, but I was ranging from chuckles to laughter when I caught onto the subtle even deadpan delivery by the characters. As a comedy, it retains a high quality of humor that uses gags effectively by cleverly redesigning the buildup so it remains fresh. How long before they stale entirely is uncertain, but the gags currently all work fine. 


The cast is superb with voicework of Tohru, Kanna and Kobayashi all deserve particular praise. Despite the comedy and energetic vibrancy the show gives, there is also a really precious theme swimming through its veins. It's a show that made me smile, even sometimes tear up on how beautiful things can be when portrayed through a medium such as animation. The best part I think of that is only the viewer will only know that warm feeling you get when you see certain scenes happen. It's a personal commitment that rewards the viewer as much as those on screen. The pacing is great with no setbacks or overuse of filler that wastes the potential of the characters. The music (as it is subjective as much as comedy) is very alluring. The opening is initially simple, but grows to be far more emotional and deep as you progress through each episode and the closing is silly yet charming.


I enjoyed this a great deal. I was enthralled by the artwork of the characters and dialogue. The finale filled me with tears and was near flawless in its execution. The need for a second season is critical as I feel some of the criticisms of certain characters need to be explained more so it can further their appeal. Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid deserves acclaim for it's accomplishments in sticking to a formula used often and throws a completely random and yet clever twist that works to the show's strengths. As I mentioned, I might not watch much animation as I use to, but with a much better understanding of art, critique and analyzing, there is no doubt that this show is a winner in my books. Watch it if you want a happy, funny and emotional time that is straight to the point and pulls off the surface level facades anyone might have when looking at this for the first time.

Story & Writing:
Kobayashi is truly the cream of the crop of its genre, embodying everything the slice-of-life genre has ever done right over the past decade. It's bouncy and energetic but also sweet and cathartic. This show's premise is a masterful balancing act between fantasy and normality. The fantasy aspect is emphasized just enough to give the characters and their daily interactions a bit of flair and intrigue, but not so much that it alienates the audience or shatters the happy-go-lucky mood of the show. It amazes me how well Kobayashi is able to grab your attention and not let go. Once the ball startsrolling in an episode, you're strapped in for good. You're sucked into the colorful and bouncy world of Kobayashi San-chi no Maid Dragon. It's funny, witty, sometimes profound, and is always a blast to watch.


One thing I cannot praise Kobayashi enough for is that it knows exactly what it is and what it wants to do; it never needlessly introduce melodrama or angst. Once in a while, the show will purposefully sneak in a serious but heartwarming moment or subtle life lesson, adding variety and depth to its message. These somber moments are sparse, ephemeral, and sweet, and I'm impressed by how well this show handles this aspect of its storytelling: it acknowledges the fact that life is not all fun and games, but while the fun lasts, make the most of it. It knows how to move on and return to its roots as a slice-of-life comedy with lovable and unique characters.  


Needless to say, the comedy in this show (or any show) might be a hit or miss depending on the person. To me, it was a bullseye. Kobayashi's set-up and delivery of punchlines is textbook and effective. There is always a certain amount of wit and cleverness in each joke, and rarely do they feel cheesy nor over-the-top. It also helps that the show does a great job of mixing up its premise, setting, and characters every other scene, and even after 13 episodes the comedy still  manages to stay fresh and interesting for the most part, something which cannot be said for a shit ton of other shows. 


tldr:

If you're looking for a lighthearted slice-of-life anime to relax to, Kobayashi san-chi no Maid Dragon is as good as it will get.

Miss Kobayashi's dragon maid was not only my favorite of the Winter 2017 season, but one of my favorite anime of all time. Like, top three. That's how much I adored this anime.

Something that looks so comedic and light-hearted at first has completely serious, solemn andtouching moments that left me in awe. It's a story that builds upon itself, seeming simple and maybe ridiculous to some in the first episode to becoming something so touching and great by the end of the series. 8/10



ART: Kyoto animation went in for this series, that's for sure! With gorgeous character designs (seriously, I could go on and on about how much I adore Kobayashi's and the dragon's designs.) that make such distinct and amazing looking characters, to some fantastic animation that never disappointed or took the lazy road. Even the backgrounds are great, having an almost watercolor feel to them. 10/10



CHARACTERS: One of the strongest aspects of an already strong anime. There's Kobayashi, a deadpan businesswoman who has trouble expressing herself and her feelings, and then Tooru, the dragon who can be just as silly as she can be solemn and cold-blooded. Tooru and Kobayashi definitely stole the show, but that doesn't mean the other characters are something to scoff at. All brimming with personality and gorgeous designs, there's not a character in this anime I just didn't like. 9/10

The slice of life/comedy genre today seems to have set parameters. The only requirements include a group of young females doing cute things, a school setting, and a few gags here and there. I understand the target audience is young adults grinding through the education system. But what if there was an anime about a middle class woman, who by sheer coincidence persuades a dragon from another dimension to be her maid? A dragon harboring hatred toward humans. Committing Armageddon would be a trivial feat for this mythical creature. However the time spent with the proclaimed "inferior species" changes her perception into something a bitmore positive. Did I mention her friend is a dragon goth-loli who can control electricity? Sounds a bit far fetched right? Welcome to Kobayashi-san Chi no Maid Dragon.


It is difficult to convey my feelings concisely when an abstract story is delivered in such a relate-able manner. There will be countless moments of impulsive laughter followed by heart warming joy. It's the kind of anime that will put a grin on your face each and every episode without fail. It will portray a perspective that you may have taken for granted, overlooked, or even are currently experiencing without a second thought. Such as being overworked to the point where even your boss is making you do his/her share. Having a close friend to grab drinks with after a long day. Arriving home to a warm welcome or even just having a place to belong. This anime has made me appreciate every relationship, every encounter, around me so much more. Because while there are some things that will never change, nothing stays the same forever.


Most of the story revolves around Kobayashi living her daily routine accompanied by her unusual maid Tooru. Throughout the series Kobayahsi attempts to educate Tooru the rules of being a proper maid as well as the guidelines of living as a human in the 21st century. This results in a handful of hilarious moments but more importantly helps the two experience something they never have previously. Such as having a place to belong or simply feeling appreciation towards someones company. Now don't take this the wrong way. This is not a suspenseful story that will bring you to tears. It is purely a goofy comedy with adorable characters in a relaxing atmosphere.


The ironic thing is the anime's story rather mediocre! However most slice of life/comedy anime are similar in this manner. What really counts are the characters and how they interact with each other. With that being said I would like to give credit where credit is due. Kobayashi-san Chi no Maid Dragon has some of the most relate-able characters in any anime I have seen to date. Not to mention the art style graciously compliments the simple but functional aspects that make this series so attractive. With animation so smooth even battle scenes seem as though they derived straight from top tier action anime. 


At the end of the day Kobayashi-san Chi no Maid Dragon is a perfect example of a slice of life/comedy done right. Relate-able characters, heartwarming relationships, and a storm of laughter. While dragons and maids may not be the stereotypical idea of a heartwarming story. I can guarantee this step outside of the box will result in a more than gratifying experience.

To spoiler-free explain the storyline, an average software programmer woman helps out a dragon (yes, you read that right) who is near death. The woman offers to let the dragon (Tooru) stay with her and says she needs a maid, so that's exactly what our dragon who can magically turn into an attractive young woman (with horns and a tail) does. As time goes on, more and more dragons find their way into Miss Kobayashi's world and do like Tohru. There we have the base of the story. 
The story got an 8 because, whilethe SoL episodes are funny and very enjoyable, the serious bents they get onto in a few episodes are often dull and uninteresting. Some of it is backstory, but many times it's backstory that only has to do with Tooru and some strange interaction she had years ago...many times to no avail as it concerns the actual story arc of the show, or minimally so. This is a minor gripe, but what really sunk it was the random, yet somehow boring, finale episode. Again, no spoilers here but it wasn't even a bad ending, just seemed random and not entertaining. It attempted to ask a deep question, but had elements that were unnecessary to explore that tangent. Like I said, everything ended fine, but being such a weak finale really made me disenchanted. 


The art is great in this, with a good mix of classical anime styles along with some of the chibi artwork we see in the ED that's very cute. The more realistic dragon animations and some of the combat was pretty neat too, almost up there with Chunibyou, but not quite as stunning on the visuals (hence the 9 instead of a 10). However there is something that is more assuredly worth mentioning, it gets its own sub-section! (see below)


*"D" is for "Dragon"*

The ecchi is sooooooo strong with this one. One of the first things you'll notice about the female dragons is all of them have ridiculous boobs (especially Lucoa) and it's not like they don't want you to notice. The anime is littered with closeups and even has boob "sound effects" as well. I felt it was pretty forced, even on a comedic scale, so to me it sort of cheapened it as possible joke material. It was just sort of worn out towards the end and just made you roll your eyes. If you're uptight about it, you may dislike this a lot, but most of it is done for comedic value and not JUST for fan service. 


The sound in this anime was great. The voice acting was excellent and the music was great too, really don't have much to say other than that I loved it! Seemed like the voices matched the characters quite well and the OP end ED were both very catchy and enjoyable. Ironic how it's hard to comment when an anime does something really well!!


Kobayashi is a decent main character and I think she is supposed to be sort of dull by design, to show that having Tooru around makes her life better and more enjoyable. The supporting characters are definitely where all the flair comes in, though I would classify Tooru as a main character rather than a supporting. For me, Tooru was pretty much my favorite character and was quite well-written. Just watching her do things in everyday life was entertaining as it was (talking about how she was going to obliterate the dust as she's cleaning the house lol). 


EVERYONE loves Kanna, but Lucoa and Elma were great characters as well. Poor Shouta seems destined to die the death every man would pray for...suffocation by Lucoa's boobs. Sometimes it got a little over-the-top with Lucoa, but many times the comedic potential was used well (the Christmas play!!). Elma was actually very funny and interesting, but she received very little development outside of just being the foodie. It was a cute schtick at first, but that's ALL they did with her. Fafnir got some exploration as a character, and it was good to see him changing and progressing through the series. Kanna was definitely adorable and deserves the notice that she gets. She was a great addition to Kobayashi and Tohru, but that brings me to my next point...


So was it enjoyable? Yes it was, but this suffered from the same problem we ran into with Ichigo Mashimaro...super uncomfortable loli sexualizing. Riko Saikawa is one of Kanna's classmates, and eventually becomes her friend. She is waaaaay attracted to Kanna and even times like when their chests touch, Saikawa practically loses it. This also happens when Kanna eats something off her finger and we get the typical super redface and omg reaction. While they didn't seem to do anything past that (no ecchi stuff or comments on their bodies), it went from being a "liking her" to something of an uncomfortable level when suggested body contact was made. That doesn't bother some people (I'm sure of that), but to those like me just a heads up. Barring all of that and the ecchi madness, this anime was funny, cute, and very entertaining. Just like with all the good ones, you go "NOOO! It's over already???" at the end of the episode. I could see this one have a lot of replay value, though you MAY want to be careful who you watch it with. 



If you like SoL comedies and don't mind a ton of boob fanservice and some ecchi as well, you will probably like this show. Get past the creepy loli sexualization and you have a fantastic show. Just watch out for the tail meat...

Kobayashi-san no Maid Dragon is a work of Kyoto Animation, the same company that has created big hits in the anime industry such as The Melancholy of Haruhi Suzumiya, Lucky Star and K-On!. But in the recent years, it works are going on a slump, with the reputation of its works losing due to the lack of plot and characters. Will this 2016 Winter anime bring it back to life?
Firstly, plot. The story focuses on Kobayashi, a programmer, and Tohru(or Tooru), a dragon which she saved while she was drunk and is now working as a maid to repay her. As the story goes on,more and more dragons from the other world comes to the human world. The jokes made seems to be forced and the connection between episode and episode is too sudden without any hints for the next episode. Besides, the story is bland even compared with other slice of life anime. But story, in SOL animes, is not really a major factor that would affect the enjoyment. 


Secondly, art. I will not talk too much about it. KyoAni has shown great art in their works. The backdrops of each scene and the direction in this anime has also shown overflowing quality. The facial expressions are smooth and the character movements are not choppy. They pick up even the slightest detail and avoid raw art unless when necessary for comedic effects.  


Thirdly, sound. I will also not focus on this part too much. The opening combined with the art brings out the theme of the anime, the ending fits with every episode to make a conclusion, and the OST was executed perfectly to bring out the mood of those scenes without making a ruckus and diverting our attention from the animation itself.


Fourthly, character. You can see the development in characters and how they develop feelings for each other. For example, Kobayashi and Kanna, one of the dragons that came to the human world, have been reliant on Tohru and cannot handle their daily affairs on their own. Kobayashi has also stood up to Tohru's father, a being that could destroy her with ease. Fafnir (again, one of the dragons) has softened his hateful attitudes to humans, at least to his gaming partner Takiya. From these examples, it is needless to say that they are mostly somewhat three dimensional characters. 


On to the character design of the stars of the show.


Kobayashi's pink, distinctive hair colour does not really give off the common, office lady feel, but her eyes show listlessness and her outfit is also common. Her personality is straight out flat, with little backstory shown. Despite that, she managed to build connection with other characters. These emphasize her ordinary office lady feel. All in all, a well designed character.


Tohru. Her orange hair, eyes, and her green tail hints more strongly than every other character about her dragon lineage, being a Western dragon. Her horns once again brings out the fact that she is a supernatural being again. Her maid costume fits nicely with the title, though it mismatches her overly eccentric and energetic personality. This, though, is what brings out her moeness per se, with some people loving those kinds of contrast.


Kanna. Her character design screams one thing. PURENESS. From the white hair, loli body shape, and her white-themed outfit, all that leads to people linking her up with an innocent figure (and what makes people including the creators wanting to lewd her). The existence of he tail that serves as a plug-in is not to bring up her real identity of being a dragon/god of thunder, but instead to emphasize her moeness along with the action of eating anything she comes across, the action that relates to babies.


Last but not least, enjoyment. I personally adore SOL anime, and while different parts of this anime do not go hand in hand, I was still unable to bring myself to relate and enjoy myself with the show. The characters, while having their own personalities and colours, are to heavily focused on that they just became too bright. The show kind of ruined itself with its characters contrasting too much with each other and unable to bring up their own unique features. We can definitely see the development of characters as said before, but they do not evolve much on their own, with none of their characters changing too much, though that is what I suppose is one of what makes SOL anime attractive. With all that said, it does not need too much jokes that will stuff the show as it is enough with the cute daily interactions with each other, beautiful drawings, and great execution. In my opinion, this anime brings everyone in it together without changing their own colours, and that's what makes this anime beautiful.

Miss Kobayashi dragon maid final review
A beautiful slice of life story about family and friends.
Story 8/10
The story that this anime portrays is about the japanese society told from the perspective of our characters who try to find their place in the human society. Its about dragons who are searching for their identity as a individual or to be more precise they try to coexist with humans and their everyday life.
The show manages to put a strong accent on the most common and lovely bond that humans have called family. Our characters who are dragons each with unique traits, experience the daily hardships of humans andhappiness too. It's one of the anime strong points, the struggle for each character to find its place and identity in the human society.


The pace is slow in the beginning we are introduced to the characters and we learn slowly about their daily habbits(where they work, how they interact with each other, what they like , hate etc). All across the show the pace is steady and slow but this doesn't affect the development of the story because it fits perfect for its genre ,slice of life.


The show also portrays human nature and transition. What's well executed is the transition which is not rushed at all, for example Tohru and Kobayashi when they move to a new place the anime takes time to let the viewer get used to the new enviroment. Tohru meets her neighbours , talks with each other, finds out about the problems in that new place.This is so relayable to a real life situation and was done in a steady and natural pace.


Human nature is well shown by the dragons personalities and habbits we have gluttony symbolized by Elma, envy and pride for Tohru, love and maturity for Kanna. Also the characters interactions influence the decisions and choices across the story.


Another subjects this anime talks about is about the bond between two persons. Sometimes can be two lovers, friends and the most important one family. The message is very strong in this show about family and Tohru Kanna and Kobayashi are a fine example to describe the word family. They care for each other and influence each other development and decisions across the anime.


About the japanese society the anime manages to portray that and shows to the viewer at a steady pace each episode using elements of comedy and drama. We are shown how they work, where the children go to school, and finally how they interact in the society. 

We are shown how hard is to raise a child, what sacrifices you need to make to be with your child and the way a family changes your perspective and actions in the society as a individual. Wonderfull.


Characters 8/10 

Our characters are a fine example on how the human society works and they symbolize aspects from the culture of japanese society.


Fafnir is our usual otaku who likes to play games and waste time all day. This also criticize how japanese society treats otaku and brings a strong message to the viewer that is not the right way to spend your life.


Tohru is the overprotective mother or friend that you can rely on it. Also her character symbolizes identity for a individual as she struggles to accept her own person as a human and not be devoured by her dragon inner strife.


Kanna is our usual human child who is curios and needs love and help from a mother. She also acts like a mature person and cares for her friends and family. A relayable character a joy and a irreplaceable treasure for every family called children.


Elma is our usual hardworking type character who likes to be independent and has a sharp memory. Luccoa is like a big sister who takes care of her little brother.


Finally Kobayashi and her otaku friend co-worker who likes to go to drinking after work. Her character development is good and influenced by other characters interactions. Also she has a maid fetish when she is drunk.

All characters are relayable to real life and well written for a slice of life genre and have unique traits and personalities.


Animation 8/10

Beautiful and vivid colors for evidentiating the feels and inner struggles of our characters.


Sound 10/10

The sound gave me goosebumps every time and a train of feels.


Enjoyment 8/10

I laughed i cried and i was amazed by the rich content and full of feels episodes from this anime.


Overall 8/10

A beautiful slice of life story portrayed by our dragon characters in the japanese society that brings a strong message to the viewer about family ,friends and how important they are. A lesson of life taught by this anime for the viewers and how to be a better person by helping in your own way the persons that are dear to you, be it family,friends,elders ,or lover.

I can easily describe this show by saying that it's a hybrid of Devil is a Part Timer and Non Non Biyori, while being worse than both. 
The majority of the scenes are what one can describe as "comfy": neither interesting or exciting, but not annoying either.  Non Non Biyori is exactly the same, but provides more visual appeal through gorgeously detailed and colored backgrounds.  In Maid Dragon, the settings are generally much more bland.  Both shows share their rare moments that are genuinely funny or endearing.  But for the most part, it's boring; in an oddly tolerable and comfortable way.


The characters are also pretty similar, with one exception, Kanna, who is a without-a-doubt-copyright-infringing-carbon-copy of Renge.  Generally lovable, kind of tropy, shallow and uninteresting, the cast of Maid Dragon does its job in delivering the gags or looking cute.  


I mentioned Maou earlier because this show is also peppered with moments of pseudo parodic chuuni battles and other dragon-related action scenes.  There's also the fact that most of the cast are almighty dragons from another world rather than mere earthlings, but who choose to live among people.  Ring a bell?  The execution of these elements is nowhere near as good as Maou's, though.  The animation is pretty mediocre and the parodies are not exaggerated enough to have a real comical impact.


Yeah.. There's not much to say about this show because not much happens within it.  And it's mostly things you've seen before.  But it's not unpleasant, so have a watch if you've got some time to kill.

KyoAni with a feel good slice of life comedy about lesbian dragons?. Pfffft SOLD!
What was somewhat a surprise even for KyoAni for LA, comes Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid from Winter of 2017 and this is undoubtably one of the better comedies of this season, even if the premise has an "uncanny valley" at first.
Well what better way to start a character-focused comedy anime than it's characters?. Let's start with Tooru, Kobayashi's dragon maid herself voiced by Yuuki Kuwahara, she is overly obsessed dragon that came to live with Kobayashi and she herself has many quirks about herself, like her insistent on feeding Kobayashi her tail(yes seriously) to her massive power level to making some of the most mundane tasks crazy as all hell what with her competitive streak, she is one of the driving forces let alone the catalyst of starting the plot AND allowing more dragons into Kobayashi's and by extensions Kobayashi's friends lives in the process and because of that she's ONE of LA's favourite characters. Next is Kanna Kamui voiced by Maria Naganawa, the next dragon to make her appearance in the series and she has an attachment to Tooru thus came to get her back, however her being a young dragon as it were, she became fascinated with the human world and started living with Tooru and Kobayashi as a surrogate daughter to them of sorts. Kanna is probably the most unpredictable of the characters mainly because of her role in both Kobayashi's house AND at school where she is constantly praised and fawned over the school and especially Riko Saikawa, once prideful and arrogant schoolmate of Kanna's turned yuri fangirl and moe squee machine (and by extension audience surrogate to those who like Kanna as a character in some sense) whenever Kanna does anything remotely moe which is A LOT even coincidentally. Outside of school, she also kinda drives the plot forward when it comes to Tooru and Kobayashi doing things as well. Next is Fafnir voiced by Daisuke Ono, a cynical dragon wanting to destroy all of humanity...instead became Kobayashi's friend Makoto Takiya voiced by Yuuichi Nakamura gaming buddy, if anything he's the cynical deadpan tsukommi to the the rest of the dragons and comedic skits but damn can his flipped expectations of a dragon wanting to burn all of humanity to the ground be reduced to an otaku gaming dragon, nonetheless welcomed addition. The next dragon however is not so, that being Quetzalcoatl voiced by Minami Takahashi a "god" accidentally summoned by Shouta voiced by Kaori Ishihara and is this resident shameless fanservice girl and her constant big boobs jiggling is a CONSTANT running gag of hers.....you can see why LA doesn't like Quetzalcoatl as much, but nonetheless she a bit more than shameless fanservice as she's one of the odd voice of reason especially concerning Tooru and Kobayashi as a "couple" in a sense. Finally we have Elma voiced by Yuuki Takada, a nemesis of Tooru wanting balance and peace in the human world instead like Fafnir, she begun working in Kobayashi's firm!, her running gag is trying to the self-sustainable and always wanting food as a bribe. She if anything has some of the best comedic skits as much as she comes MUCH later in the anime. Finally, Kobayashi herself voiced by Mutsumi Tamura, a stoic working programmer...at first but as she, Tooru and Kanna start living together she changes for the better as well as being the control factor to the dragons when they try going too far in their antics (especially Tooru) and really Tooru and Kobayashi's relationship is a defining factor to the anime.


LA will say the obvious, but this cast has AMAZING chemistry together and they work off together for very funny character jabbing and quick punchlines and with this character chemistry also comes the "feel good" in the comedy as essentially, it's a slice of life look at shapeshifting dragons that can turn human living with a human and the implications it has, be it good for the dragons or Kobayashi or the bad especially concerning Kobayashi and Tooru's relationship. 


This slice of life comedy looks into the family issues of such as morality (considering Tooru is an "immortal dragon" with Kobayashi's human lifespan) to helping each other grow as a person (Kobayashi with opening herself more with interacting with Tooru and the rest of the dragons to Tooru opening herself to human kind). This comedy is also unpredictable what with DRAGONS let alone shapeshifting ones into the mix as the comedy ranges from household mundane with a punchline to dragons fighting an epic battle as "fun" to school antics with Kanna and Riko to Fafnir and Makoto talking about gaming and doujin's etc. This anime kinda got most of it covered and the punchlines are GREAT in the sense because of the unpredictably let alone the dragon's running gags DON'T get old as they are used both sparingly and evolves with it's characters sans Lucoa and Fafnir but nonetheless the comedy is genuinely funny at times!


In terms of animation by KyoAni, the animation has varying degrees of detail, from moe overload with the very exotic designs of the dragons characters (both as a dragon, human form and concerning Kanna and Tooru, their semi-dragon human forms). There are out and about battles (for fun most of the time) and even the detail there has top notch animation to impeccable detail sometimes akin to a shounen!. The one odd thing LA will note is the uncanny resemblance Kobayashi's character design, it reminds LA HEAVILY of Ryuuichi Baba's character designs from Danna ga Nani wo Itteiru ka Wakaranai Ken. Nonetheless, even for a slice of life comedy anime, KyoAni pulled out all the stops even with this with LA giving high praise to the character designs and the shounen-esque battles.


In terms of voice acting, LA will say that Yuuki Kuwahara did exceptional as Tooru, bringing in the right amount of genki and "non-annoyance moe" vocals for LA to say that she's LA's favourite voice actor for this anime. Mutsumi Tamura was pretty decent in voicing Kobayashi and the subtle nod to her voice role just the reverse is happening *cough* Sayaka Dejima *cough*.
