Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid in my view is an anime about personality development and change. Even among anime it does an outstanding job about how smoothly, almost unnoticeably, but still deeply it changes its main characters. Although the story offers nothing especially new in the slice of life genre (telling about the life of a working woman and two adorable young girls), it still offers great characterization and meaningful messages under a funny, cute and very entertaining surface.
The show is about Miss Kobayashi (a software engineer in her mid-twenties) and how her life changes after she takes in two girls,Tohru and Kanna, who are actually dragons from another world. They have the ability to use magic and turn themselves into cute girls, making it easier for themselves to blend into society. Tohru is like any teenage girl: friendly, kind, loudmouth, and overly obsessed with Kobayashi. She does everything her master asks from her, even without the smallest sign of gratitude. Kanna plays the role of the cute little sister, the smallest member of the family who gets everyone's love, admiration and most of Kobayashi's attention, which bears jealousy in Tohru; a feeling what makes the elder girl an even more complex character.\n
Despite the fact that Tohru and Kanna are mighty, mythical creatures, they act and feel very much like any human. They can be equally happy and sad, and also very hysterical sometimes. They're excited to learn new things and meet new people, and sometimes (as children occasionally do) they conceal their real feelings and emotions from others, especially from Kobayashi, who, in contrast with the sparkling dragon-girls, is more like a little gray mouse.\n
Kobayashi is an ordinary, featureless woman: small breasted, bespectacled, who wears shirts with ties at work and hoodies at home; nothing sexy or cute from her part. Her days are pointless, free from any excitement, all about working and drinking with her only friend, Takiya. She's a loner, who must adapt to living together with and taking care of two girls. Even though Tohru becomes her maid and does every chores for her, Kobayashi still has to make her own sacrifices for her new family. Although she struggles with it initially, as the show progresses she grows slowly and unwittingly from the selfish, careless woman into a responsible mother, one who learns how to take care of others, how to love, and how to be loved. She realizes the small changes in her personality only when someone (usually Takiya) highlights it for her, as she herself is already forgotten about her former self. Just like people change in real life.\n
Tohru changes almost in the same degree as Kobayashi. The dragon who initially despises humanity turns out to be fascinated by them. The main catalyst in her alteration is obviously Kobayashi who didn't just let her stay at her place, but actually saved her life before. Thanks to her, Tohru realizes that humans can be more than a race which hunts and slays dragons, that they can be good, kind and caring, and are able to achieve great things together. By the end of the show, Tohru herself becomes almost as much a human as a dragon, admitting that she belongs now more into the human world than the one she hails from.\n
The character designs of Tohru and Kanna are pieces of masterful art themselves. You can't help but love both of them. The energy and girlishness which comes from Tohru's personality and Kanna's extreme cuteness are the results of not just the art department, but also the seiyuu who actually bring the characters to life. They're both charming, adorable, and really, really cute. You just can't get enough of them.\n
Unfortunately I can't speak so high about the supporting characters. They're well-designed, too, Riko is also a cutie, but most of them (save for Takiya perhaps) are as boring and empty as the main characters are rich and exciting. They have no real purpose in the story at all. You can't help but to have the feeling that those characters are only in the show to replay the same gags over and over again, which are not just boring after the first one or two times, but can be really annoying and infuriating. Repeating the same jokes multiple times, especially within the same episode, is just not funny at all. Fortunately, the main characters compensate us for everything.\n
The background design is made in a low-detailed style, which makes the characters more prominent and more focused. The backgrounds and the environment are like sketchy pencil drawings, which looks really good and serves the show perfectly.\n
The music was a little bit strange to my ears in the beginning, but I got used to it after a few episodes. The opening and ending themes are perfect, they instantly brings the mood for the show. I couldn't get them out of my mind even days after I've finished the series.\n
Although it's a comedy anime, it's not a laughing out loud type. The funny elements come from the personalities and interactions of the three main characters: how Tohru and Kanna see our world and humanity, and how they get on with Kobayashi and with each other. You won't laugh much, but I guarantee you that you won't be able to wipe the smile off your face while you're watching this show. That's what Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid's true virtue is. It makes you smile and forget all your troubles and problems for that twenty-four minutes its episodes last. It's an easy to watch anime (although it tends to spin up every now and then), which turns off your mind and just entertains you. It has fantasy elements (we're speaking about dragons here), but those are cursory, just like the drama aspect of the show, which is so negligible that it's almost none-existent at all. It's not a perfect anime, it has it's pros and cons, but if you can ignore some fanserivce and a few annoying characters, and you do not expect a twisted story, you'll be highly rewarded.\n

A new meaning for the term D-cup! Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid....is exactly that. Its the slice of life adventure of a woman(Kobayashi) and her newly "indebted" maid dragon Tohru. And its your basic mythological creature interacts with our world adventure.
The trailer of this series is criminally misleading. All the promotional material is for that matter. It makes it look like your typical fetish harem made for socially awkward guys and girls. And at times it can be. But its not just fetishy. Tohru does feel attraction to Kobayashi from the start but its handled very slowly. Their relationship is very much allowed to blossom andisn't just a after three episodes their in love kind of deal. Its even safe to say by the end of the first season its debatable if they're even in a romantic relationship.


Not to mention this is funny writing. I laughed very hard at several on the jokes  that I missed the next joke. I had to pause the show several times I found it so funny. There's the typical jokes you'd expect, people freaking out about a dragon. But theres also lines that make you think for a second and laugh at the obscurity. This mainly comes from the dragons being ignorant of typical humans stuff, but at the same time isnt what you'd expect. There's no five minute "this is a microwave!" Jokes like that, its more of them not understanding things in our world that don't make sense, but since were so use to the way things are. That when the dragons call it out its very funny. The best example of the comedy is theyre explaining the little match girl to Tohru. And they get to the part where the girls grandma takes her to heavan via hug. Tohru just flat out says "So the grandma murdered her granddaughter." And its so shocking its hilarious. And the shows full of this kind of comedy.


So lets take a look at our leading lass Kobayashi. She's fun. This is very much a character were suppose to step into the shoes of. But that doesn't mean she's completely not her own thing. She's snarky, sarcastic, hard working, and surprisingly doesn't take any of the dragons crap. But isn't a Tsundure, she's a woman who had magical beings thrusted into her life and its her job to keep it together and put them in their place. Despite this she still has her great qualities she's very motherly to Canna the youngest dragon, she goes out drinking, she has tons of snarky comments, and is all around a good protagonist. Tohru is the perfect match to her. She's easily excitable, hardworking, friendly(after she gets use to humans), and all around fun to watch. While having her own silly moments. One of the running gags it trying to get people to eat her tail.


The other dragons all have good moments too Canna(little white one) starts off weak, as a typical tsundure. But after fifteen minutes turns into a pretty adorable fan favourite. She has some of the funnier lines in the show. And her and Kobayashi's relationship is something special. Luccoa(green hair) is nice enough, Elma(blue) isn't in it much but when she is, has a very one note personality and that is hungry so don't expect much, and Fafnir(Dude) is the typical "I hate humans" god complex that finds a love for gaming. 


All and all in a show motivated by characters they are all very interesting and I love the designs. For each character they're given a nice recognizable vivid color scheme. Its actually very good at blending with the colorful yet simple background the world has to offer.

The music....exists. With slice of life shows unless the music is used to add drama it goes right over my head. But the intro and ending themes are both very catchy, dare I say stuck in your head worthy.


The only real criticism I have with the show is how its handles the kids in certain situations. Starting with Luccoa and her human Shouta. The main joke is she has big boobs and hes nervous about them. Thats all well and good but Shouta is a child! Like he's ten years old and they treat her constantly shoving her breasts all over his face as a running gag! And to make it worse Canna is given a subplot with her human friend. It's very tough for me to enjoy something that's *not* Romance. But I'm a big fan of comedy too and Kobayashi San is an excellent example of comedy and slice of life done right!
Story: 7/10
Being a Slice of Life, it's a given that there'll be zero plot progression. It's just the daily life of the characters. That said, it's a very fun and cute take at a daily life of a depressed Kobayashi, a cheerful Tohru and the cutest thing in the world, Kanna. Their interactions and hilarious takes at how to adjust with the human world is really something cute and fun to watchtoo. Kobayashi San is one of those few anime that *actually made me laugh*. Other comedies would make me smile, but I haven't laughed this much since KonoSuba!


Art: 9/10


The artstyle is something new and refreshing to watch, I really enjoyed how it looked, it excellently matched the mood of the anime as well as accentuated the Moe moments (which were many too!!!)


Sound: 10/10


Perfectly chosen VAs and perhaps the first time in a long time that *both* the OP and ED of an anime were great make this anime's sound rating a full on 10. Sometimes an anime gets a good OP, or sometimes none are great but for Kobayashi San *both* were great, and this is incredible in a sense too. Aozora no Rhapsody and Ishukan Communication were both catchy and immersive. Another plus point goes to the OST, perfectly fitting the mood and adding to the Moe power in it's respect moments too.


Characters: 8/10


Zero plot progression also means that the characters have to be great from the start, or else deal with the low ratings, but Kobayashi San's characters were great right from the start. Thankfully the MC is a woman or else if it was a teenage boy then things would *seriously* go south (as in it would be an Ecchi Romance misadventure to feed the snotty teens of today). 


Kobayashi: The MC, Kobayashi lived a very normal life and has a cynical view of life. She changes slowly when Tohru becomes her maid. Though hints are given throughout the anime that her cynical worldview isn't completely gone, it does get toned down. 


Tohru: Found by Kobayashi under 'mysterious circumstances', Tohru quickly gets hired as a personal maid for Kobayashi and tries to learn the working of the world. Other dragons do join her (one of just favourites being Fafnir San apart from Kanna of course) but they're role is limited even for supporting actors. 


Enjoyment: 10/10


Not gonna lie, I seriously laughed while watching the anime. At most I would smile at other comedies (though KonoSuba is the only other anime series I ever laughed at) but Kobayashi San is a really good comedy. If you're in it for the the comedy like I was then you'll definitely not be disappointed. Mark my words!


Overall: 9/10


Being a Slice of Life Comedy, you can't judge the anime for having no plot progression as thats not what the anime intends to do. The anime is a worthy watch if you're a Comedy fan or a Slice of Life fan. Personally speaking this is one of my top favourites of 2017!

I may have made the grave mistake of comparing an anime to it's source material, but at the same time I, by doing so, found out just how /amazing/ Kyo-ani is at adaptions.
At first glance, the premise and characters of Meidoragon are nothing special--and I'll admit that they stay so. Kobayashi starts as a dead-eyed OL and stays one, Tohru is a dragon who's a maid and continues to be, and the rest... you get my flow. The premise, though interesting, doesn't stick out much either. What's truly captivating about this show are the relationships.
No, don't get me wrong, I don't mean the KobayashiTohru yuriaction. I meant the bonds between the characters and how you see them growing as the series progresses. It's done nicely and subtly so that you barely realize it happens at all, but when you compare the first episode to the last, you'll see the difference between how the characters interact. One scene in which this really stands out is when Shouta practices banishing demons on Lucoa, and Lucoa runs out. There're a lot of scenes in between of different characters (as this is the storytelling style of Meidoragon), but when we cut back to Shouta we see him panicking and running out to find Lucoa (she's out there petting a kitten, don't worry). This is significantly different from how Shouta treats and sees Lucoa in the start of the anime: a demon succubus that he must get rid of.


Back to what I said about the characters staying the same. The thing about Meidoragon is that the characters don't necessarily grow, they discover. The characters (especially Kobayashi and Tohru) are invited to dig deeper into their inner souls (is this an exaggeration? I hope I'm not exaggerating it too much) and discovering things about themselves that allows them to unlock parts of themselves they never knew existed. I think this is called development, but I seriously wouldn't call it that in this case. Call me stubborn, but the characters don't get over, say, a fatal flaw that allows them to progress further in life. They learn to get the most from the current situation, and even though that's staying where they are, it's nice to see them having a good time from it.


The animation and art are amazing as always, nothing less than what I'd expect from Kyo-ani.


Now to the controversial part. This show fully shows Kyo-ani's abilities to adapt because it was so drastically improved once it was animated by Kyo-ani. Many of the order of events were changed to increase the meaning of them (eg. Shouta was introduced earlier), and new gags were rightfully placed to enhance the viewing experience in general. Kyo-ani also added the humanity into it, in my opinion. The original manga was about 60% fanservice, 30% plot that is also fanservice, and 10% actual character interaction and development. Kyo-ani changes this 30% so it takes up more of the pie that is Meidoragon (taking away some from the 60% of fanservice). As a result, characters got better, character motives were clearer, and the emotional impact from the last few episodes got insanely larger. 


Call me biased, but I totally bought the whole sweet domestic fluff thing (and how Kyo-ani adapted source material in general), which is why I'd give this anime a 10.

I remember this show being all the craze last season. Everyone was watching it. Everyone was praising it. Needless to say, for a show that didn't initially grab my attention, I was intrigued. By the time the show had ended and went for free on Crunchyroll, I decided to get into it, and I am happy to report that I did not enjoy it whatsoever. It ended up being an incredibly shallow show, with lots of pointless fanservice that culminated to absolutely nothing. A very weak lead with an even weaker deuteragonist, with a hollow relationship with the only benefit that attracted all these peoplein the first place was because it was about a lesbian couple, because diversity without proper character writing sure does work, doesn't it? I sure do have a lot to say about this show and I can't wait to sink my teeth into it to talk about how much I despise this show, because if you haven't realized by now, I'm actually fucking with you and I genuinely enjoyed this show albeit some caveats that I'd like to discuss. First, let's focus on the positives.


Miss Kobayashi's Maid Dragon is primarily a comedy anime, and as far as comedy goes, it does that aspect pretty well. You can definitely see KyoAni's usual influence for its shows on top of the original writer's unique sense of humor. A dash of cute and adorable slice-of-life often broken up by sudden instances of subtle dark humor. Many of the show's elements contribute to how well-delivered a lot of the jokes are. KyoAni abandons it's unique art style and lighting effects exhibited in most of its shows to deliver a more down-to-earth and simple art style to better reflect the comical nature of the show. A visible downgrade from the standards set by the studio? Maybe. However, the comedy in this show wouldn't have worked that well if everyone had highly-detailed eyes or hair in my opinion, so I think this change of style is welcome especially in place of a style frequently used by the same studio. In addition, the studio does go overboard with some details put into specific key animations, often which are used for comedic effect.


For the characters and how they help enhance the humor, you have Kobayashi's dead-serious done-with-this-shit attitude for many of Tohru's misfits; Tohru's usual petite and cheerful tone suddenly shifting to downright malicious; Kanna's often deadpan and monotone yet also innocent behavior to reflect awkward reactions to comedic effect; Lucoa's clueless but good-spirited demeanor; and Fafnir's overly-edgy and constant malignancy towards very silly and trivial activities. In addition to the rest of the cast, these characters work by fulfilling certain tropes only to then subvert your expectations of them completely when the time is right. The (original) voice actors even do a great job at portraying each character in very believable yet hilarious ways.


Of course, it doesn't just stop at the comedy. Over the course of the show, the characters tend to show some subtle hints of progression. Overtime, they start exhibiting tiny new changes as they learn from one another. Some recurring jokes in the show are delivered differently each time, by keeping what is necessary the same and changing what needs to be changed to keep them interesting, be it the delivery, the punchline, or how the characters react. Those same jokes help mirror just how much the characters have changed throughout the show's course. One of my least favorite moments is when the show tries to remind you by how much certain characters have changed, because it already does a good job at portraying that subtly without even needing to tell us directly.


Of course, the big elephant in the room is the relationship between Kobayashi and Tohru and how it's a big deal for lesbian, and potentially even queer or ace, leads. To some, this might be the whole point of the show or might be why so many praise it so much, but as someone who can't really identify with the characters from that avenue, I can only find it as a neat little bonus on top of an already-good show. However, I did pay attention to some of the smaller little hints the show exhibits for both our two main leads in terms of trying to examine certain subsets of people that often don't get enough exposure in entertainment, and I do appreciate the show all the more for doing so. I have friends who are heavily-invested in this show for feeling like they've been well-represented themselves, and if many others feel the same way, then this show is certainly doing something right.


Aside from the talk about diversity, the relationship is genuine. As both our leads continue to interact with one another, they start to accordingly modify their personalities or even exhibit opposite ones more akin to their partner's, to the point that they don't feel like the same people once the show is over. The show makes you feel the hardships they endure throughout their journey, eventually leading to a rather satisfying climax. Along the way, there are small cues here and there about how one feels about the other during certain scenarios, without completely revealing everything to the viewer. The characters can often be unpredictable but at the same time human, and they often can't fully explain why they feel a certain way yet those feelings resonate with the audience. Sure, some of their actions can be silly or cumbersome, but people in general do commit those actions inexplicably as well, so the characters aren't completely unbelievable but genuinely humane. I can safely say that this show handled its main romantic leads very well, and hopefully this show will be looked back to because of it.


For some of the stuff that I didn't like in the show, there's quite a few. Before I begin, I'll discuss some of the more controversial aspects of the show later.


One of my biggest complaints is simply how, well, monotonous it can be at times. True, it is a slice-of-life and that is to be expected; however, I feel like this show needed quite a few more inventive scenarios rather than just "beach episode" or "sports festival episode" or "friend's house" episode. I've seen events like these in many other shows, and outside of character development, there's not really a whole lot interesting or new about them. Kobayashi's flat as well as the market they frequent contribute to 75% of the show's locales. Even if you do decide to stick to only a handful of locations, you could at least try to keep us more invested in the events and how they plan out, yet the show never does that. There's no real drive or motivation to suddenly be invested in the plot related to each specific event. I feel like this aspect is the weakest part about this show.


On top of that, there are definitely characters that needed more development, even if side characters. Kobayashi's friend from work is certainly the biggest candidate in dire need of development, immediately followed by Saikawa and Fafnir. I understand that the show is mostly centered around our leads, but we've already been given very interesting side characters that I would have loved to have known a lot more about, yet the show never takes that route. I guess one minor gripe is that the show could have shown us a lot more about Tohru's world, but I suppose that would completely change the whole point of the show; plus, we do get small glimpses of Tohru's past every once in a while. I just wished that I could see more, hell, maybe even from the other characters' points of views or even THEIR pasts too. Also, not a fan of the bits where the show tries to remind you how much the characters have changed overtime, because it already does a great job at showing that in subtle yet meaningful ways.


[Disclaimer]

I do like this show, but one thing I should point out about this show is the controversial element surrounding it, which I feel could be a deal breaker to some people. Now it would seem that one of the characters is frequently used as the butt of many uncomfortable jokes due to her bust size. Some of these jokes can border around straight-up pedophilia. Perhaps jokes like these are generally acceptable by Japan's culture (I wouldn't know for sure), but for western cultures, some of these jokes can be seen in bad taste. I personally didn't mind them all that much despite finding them somewhat off, but the same can't be said about everyone. Some will be more accepting of those jokes, others even less so or would even prefer to avoid those jokes altogether. It's really up to you decide whether this would be a deal-breaker for you, or if you'd be fine with that content included.


--------------------------------------


To summarize, Miss Kobayashi's Maid Dragon is quite an enjoyable comedy with a great romantic lead. While lacking in writing in some less-important areas, it manages to deliver a fun and charming story about the supernatural encountering the mundane. The romance in this show is genuinely-enjoyable with great writing and character development from start to end. With the recent influx of monster girls adapting to everyday life, I can definitely say that Miss Kobayashi's Maid Dragon is one of the better stand-out examples. A fulfilling show about a IT office nerd and her lover deudoragonist. Definitely worth checking out if it tickles you fancy.

Let's see...I only watched this anime because I saw one of my anime youtubers (Anme Man or Akidearest I forget) do a first impression of it. They didn't really say much about it, but I was intrigued by the plot summary. Now generally I don't like slice of life, and the fact that it looked like a cute girl anime only further lowered my expectations as I watched the first episode. But I was immediately hooked within minutes. 
In many ways I was right. Yes, it was a slice of life anime, and yes, it had many cute girl elements. But something about it madeit so appealing. Maybe it was the fact that Kobayashi was completely disinterested with interacting with dragons, or maybe how endearing Tohru is. I think what I liked the best about this show was the character dynamics. Tohru, despite being so much more powerful than Kobayashi, and could easily destroy the planet, trying so hard to please and hilariously failing is interesting and very funny to see. I also loved the bromance of Fafnir and Takiya, though not much of their interactions is shown, the few bits that are featured are so dorky and awesome.


Not everything in the show is all fun and rainbows though. Sprinkled throughout the episodes are moments that feel just the slightest bit off. Usually its through the inner monologue of one of the dragons, where they remind the viewer that what they are seeing could be easily broken. The dragons still hold so much power over the humans, and could easily kill everyone if rubbed the wrong way. But as the series progresses, you can see their views change a bit, and some of them actually starting to see humans as equals.


I should stop rambling. Here are the other bits:


Story - Not much of an umbrella plot, as expected of a slice of life anime, most of the show just shows some parts of the characters daily chaotic lives with dragons, which is equally amusing. I won't spoil, but by the end there is a more serious tone.


Art - Their designs are what you would expect for a cute girl show, but there are some points where the animation really goes beyond what is needed. Very beautiful.


Character - Once again, what you would expect of a cute girl show, but it is the character dynamics that are really fun. Especially the growing relationship of Kobayashi and Tohru.


Enjoyment - Seriously, this anime hooked me instantly. It's fun, bubbly, entertaining. What more could you ask for?


Even if you don't like the SOL genre like I did, I still recommend this fully.

Move out of the way, catgirls! We've got a new thing coming from Japan, and those are dragon girls! As if that's not enough, they've got dragon girls that are maids! In all seriousness, I first discovered this anime when I found out it was getting an anime adaptation; I was, at first, just slightly intrigued because of it being based off of the same mangaka as Danna ga Nani wo Itteiru ka Wakaranai Ken, but when it was announced that Kyoto Animation would be the animation studio behind it, I decided that I was going to watch it for sure. I even read themanga to prepare myself for the anime, and it was rather amusing, to say the least. Despite all of this, however, I still wasn't prepared for exactly how good this anime was going to be.


Ladies and gentlemen, dragon maids all around, here is my review of "Kobayashi-san Chi no Maid Dragon", known in English as "Miss Kobayashi's Dragon Maid".


Kobayashi-san Chi no Maid Dragon begins when Kobayashi, an office worker, finds a dragon standing at her door that day; the dragon then proceeds to transform into a cute girl with D (for dragon)-cup breasts and introduces herself as Tohru.  As it turns out, Kobayashi and Tohru met on the mountains one night when the former had taken a drunken excursion there and the latter got defeated and fled to this other world; seeing that she had nowhere to go, Kobayashi offers Tohru to live with her. As a result, Tohru has arrived to not only accept her offer, but she has also become her maid! Albeit reluctant at first, Kobayashi agrees to let Tohru stay. With Tohru around, it's needless to say that Kobayashi's life has gotten more interesting, especially with other dragons arriving in this world, too.


I'll say this first, just to get it out of the way and prevent me gushing over it too much; the animation from Kyoto Animation is, once again, a sight to behold. With its fluid movement, simple (although simplicity is perfect for an anime like this) backgrounds, and cute character designs, it goes without question that the folks at KyoAni has provided excellent animation once more. The voice acting is pretty solid, too; the voice actors do their best with their respective roles, and not only do they succeed, they also seem to be having fun with their roles. The opening and ending themes, which are respectively "Aozora no Rhapsody" by fhana and "Isshuukan Communication" by Choro-gonzu (the seiyuus for Tohru, Kanna, Elma, and Lucoa), are also excellent songs that both fit this anime's atmosphere to a T.


As for the story, it's rather simplistic; if you're looking for an anime that has both dragons and a complicated plot, you're not going to find the latter, so unless you're just going to settle for the dragons, I suggest looking elsewhere. It's not a huge problem for me, though; as a fan of slice of life anime, I enjoyed the story this anime had to tell. There were also quite a few jokes that were thrown my way that made me bust up laughing. For example, there is one running gag where one character, Saikawa, goes crazy for another character, Kanna, in certain situations; those moments never failed to make me laugh, especially because of the facial expressions she has as a result.


Now, let's talk about the driving force behind Kobayashi-san Chi no Maid Dragon, and that is its characters. Kobayashi is a rather standard protagonist, but even she has her moments of amusement; that, along with the strong bonds she has with Tohru, Kanna, and other characters in the series, made her a great character through my eyes. If you said to me a few months ago that Dragon Maid was actually a good show I think I would've honestly slapped you in the face. One of the things that I think most people will definitely love about this series is its surprisingly great writing and humour. Then their's of course our other title character the Dragon Maid Tohru.  Tohru is honestly just such a bright and bubbly personality all on her own.  Although she sort of fills in the "being from another world" trope thats quite apparent  you see her easily fitting through society while still maintaining that bubbly personality. I'll also admit that at times I did feel bored, especially between episodes 7 and 10.


However despite those flaws Dragon Maid is great.  It was some of the most enjoyable weeks I had in watching a series and man would I just love to see more. TL:DR: Kobayashi's Maid-Dragon is a blissfully, beautiful anime about what it means to be a family. Story: 9


The story of Kobayashi's Dragon Maid follows the lives of its three main characters Kanna, Tohru, and Kobayashi. While, it does take their lives, generally, one giant plot point at time (examples: cultural assimilation and school). Its story actually creates a wholesome argument about what it means to be a family, which this anime argues is that families are created from groups of people who instinctively can tell each other they love and trust one another. The best episode that envisions comes from revolves around the idea of family is episode 8 (written by Fumihiko Shimo) and 9 (written by Director Yasuhiro Takemoto), where the focus revolves around the Mother-Daughter dynamic between Kanna and Kobayashi. While, I enjoy the theme and importance of family to the story of this anime. It is definitely not a unique topic that has been tried and tested to great success with other anime like Sweetness and Lightning, The Eccentric Family, and Fruits Basket. Each of those anime gave their own perspective of the idea of family that I thought was more unique when I compare them to Kobayashi's Maid-Dragon.  However, the reason the story still gets a 9 is because the story flows incredibly well and the dialogue between the characters is extremely funny to listen to. Watch the beginning of episode 8 to understand what I mean or the magic show scene in episode 5. These scenes represent some of the best Kobayashi has to offer in terms of character dialogue.


I would be remiss though if I did not talk about the filler episodes such as the Beach Episode and Comiket. Both of these episodes drag the viewer away from this wholesome story and devolve the show into a more fan-service orientation. Not to say that those episodes were bad, it was just something that I wish those script and screenwriters could have still revolved this idea of family, instead of just going for fan-service and comedy. Kobayashi's Maid-Dragon's story may not be the most ground-breaking or thought-provoking, but executes its theme with grace and nice comedic taste.


Art: 8


The art is Kobayashi's Maid-Dragon is exactly where anyone should expect Kyoto Animation's to be. It's cute, glossy with bright colors, and flows extremely well from scene to scene. Additionally, like KyoAni fashion, its opening is breathtaking beautiful. The opening few seconds where the backgrounds shift out of focus before snapping into character portraits not only introduces us to the main characters of the show, but sets the viewer up well to understand that this is going to be a quirky, fun show. There are a few times in the middle episodes where Tohru's animations tend to get a bit too stiff. But, is not disruptive enough to cause big problems. Dragon-Maid's art gets a thumbs up from me.


Sound: 8


The soundtrack in Kobayashi's Maid-Dragon is more or less forgettable. The opening and ending for this show is incredibly catchy, and the cute sound effects that accompanies Tohru and Kanna really add a childish dimension to their character. However, the sound in this anime is probably its weakest point because it only has a couple standout tracks with a great opening track from fHana and a fun ending track from the female VAs.


Characters: 10


Maid-Dragon completely banks on its characters for the entire series to propel itself into success because it aims to be a pure comedy, slice-of-life. Therefore, the focus of the anime is based on the antics and reactions of the characters in its story. Kobayashi's definitely kill it, and are extremely hilarious to watch from episode 1 to episode 12. They are not completely unique by any degree because some characters like Kanna resemble Renge (Non Non Biyori) and Kobayashi resembles any working mother. From that standpoint, it should make the characters in this anime rather bland because of their lack of unique character design. Except, the VAs did a great job at creating evocative characters and their reactions to make them easy to relate to and funny to watch.


Overall: 9


Kobayashi's Maid-Dragon came out of left field. This show, on the outside, looks like a standard, boring slice-of-life with comedic aspects. Except, Kyoto Animation's director Yasuhiro Takemoto brought life into this project by having an anime that talks about what makes a family, including its ups and downs. The story is also masterfully chereographed in tandem with the brilliant visuals that people should expect to come Kyoto Animation. Therefore, this anime asks the question is it time for KyoAni to come back into a top 5 animation studio with the likes of Ufotable, Ghibli, Madhouse, and Bones? Or, is their current sprees of success (A Silent Voice, Sound Euphonium, and Free) just a stint of success before falling back down into a position of 6-10? I would argue that Kobayashi's Maid-Dragon makes a strong argument that Kyoto Animation wants to become a top 5 animation studio.

I don't know if there is any other media in the world that could possibly pull off the things anime get away with. I just like to imagine a Hollywood production company trying to pitch a story about a dragon that turns into a cute little girl and wants to be the best maid there ever was to a room of TV show producers. Anime is truly an art that has mastered the ways of traversing the thin line between insanity and brilliance. Although, this isn't to say that there is anything particularly brilliant about Kobayashi san chi no Maid Dragon, but it is definitelybrings out the sunshine after a long, dreary day. 


In a world of moe with a sea of anime about cute girls doing cute things, how exactly does Kobayashi san chi no Maid Dragon (for short I'll call it simply "Kobayashi san" for the duration of this review) stand out from other shows similar to its premise? To be honest, there isn't too much different from many of the others considering it isn't the first to have cute girls who are actually a creature or beast of some sort that just happened to fall in love with some human who for whatever reason is constantly compelled to reject their love while keeping them around out of charity until love slowly blossoms in them as well. But while this is the formula that constitutes the premise of the show, Kobayashi san does take liberties with some minor details including the sex of the recipient of the cute girl's love. 


The "hero" of our story, who is the one the audience is meant to project themselves onto thus emulating a feeling of ourselves being the recipient of the cute girl's emotions, is a woman herself. Yuri isn't uncommon but I rarely see it used in this formula which was originally designed as male fantasy. This small tweak is in its own way a great tactic to expanding the audience because it includes both male and female viewers into the fantasy. The reason for this is the design and character of Kobayashi, who while being a female doesn't act like any other female characters in this show as she can appear very masculine and has less articulated sexuality in her appearance. At the same time, there are clear visual indications that Kobayashi is female (example: pony tail). Also, her reserved attitude, often silent demeanor, and her small eyes give her a sort of grey slate where she is allotted enough character to let her feel like her own person while also giving the audience some space to project their own self image onto her. She isn't bound too heavily to her masculinity or femininity, but she doesn't lack these to the point where she feels genderless and sterile. Her being a woman also gives a reasonable excuse to deny the cute girl's loving advances because she did not indicate being homosexual; this kind of trope is harder to pull off with male characters because it usually requires some sort of plot devise to keep him distant (the same could be said for clearly homosexual women). Other than this nice little tweak, Kobayashi doesn't add much else to the show other than being a sort of stand-in for the audience. 


Now, the show's true charm is brought in with the other titular character, the Maid Dragon. Named Tohru, she is a dragon who falls in love with Kobayashi when she met her drunk and in the mountains. Kobayashi drunkenly invites her to live at her place and is later obligated to allow Tohru to live with her working as a maid. The rest of the show doesn't stray too far from this original concept and the episodes are mainly dedicated to displaying Tohru's endearing efforts to become the best maid she possibly can and the people and situations that come with what that entails. The character of Tohru truly makes this show by being a positive and outgoing girl with a past depicted from the image of RPG fantasy dragons and their violent relationship with humans creating a sense of new perspective on a familiar setting. Tohru's past is clearly stated but we learn enough of what we need to know to understand and feel emotional connection to her, and Tohru's bias of humans, shaped by these past events, add for some nice little moments of growth and development for her along the way as she observes how Kobayashi interacts in society. There are a few nice points in the show that define and demonstrate the inner workings of human society in a way that Tohru can understand and learn from which allows her to grow into the lovable dragon maid she is towards the end of the season. 


These are all mostly positive points on the show, but there are certainly negatives that I need to address. My first, small critique is on Kanna, the young loli dragon that appears immediately after Tohru. In contrast to Tohru's energetic expressiveness, I believe Kanna does add a nice opposite by being straight faced and monotone and the animators know exactly how to articulate this to match her childish nature to make the ultimate machine of cuteness. However, I do find it rather off-putting when I feel like the show is attempting to sell her look sexually even though she is only in elementary school. Her design is a bit too curvy and flashy for a child of her age and the directing attempts to utilize her looks as a means of enticing the viewer. I don't have a problem with cute little girls, I just simply have difficulty appreciating her slight sexual nature. 


My second critique is a bit wider as it can encompasses a few of the most recent episodes. I really enjoyed the beginning up until the middle as I felt it had charm, personality, and a unique voice. Unfortunately, the show continues and some episodes end up as manufactured arcs that appear in most other shows of this genre (i.e. beach episode, Christmas episode, new year's episode, hot spring episode, etc.). This feels like Kobayashi san is going off of a template limiting itself to the 'tried and true' design of its predecessors. There is definitely lost potential in these episodes as they often end up being the standard having fun with the friend group and ending on a heart-warming note with not much substance in between. The best jokes and funny moments are only in the beginning with the show losing some of the comical momentum and relying more on dialogue and static situations between friends. This isn't necessarily a bad thing considering the Comiket episode was fairly enjoyable. But the other episodes just can't help but fall short of the more original events of the earlier ones. 


Despite this, Kobayashi san still carries a wonderful and charming feeling of energy and pleasure that makes each episode leaving you warm and fuzzy inside. Overall, I definitely think Kobayashi san is in the top 3 new anime this season and is worth a visit to those who have yet to try it.
